"id": "430558", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bud Black"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bud_Black", "score": 2, "id": "742618", "type": "person"}], "body": "Former New York Yankees player Derek Jeter waved to fans during a ceremony retiring his number at Yankee Stadium in New York. A person familiar with the negotiations said the Miami Marlins have told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes Jeter.\n\nThe Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes the former New York Yankees captain, a person familiar with the negotiations said today.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented.\n\nThe Marlins' months-long sale saga included many twists before owner Jeffrey Loria settled on the popular Jeter, who led the Yankees to five World Series championships before retiring after the 2014 season.\n\nThe person speaking on condition of anonymity said MLB was told Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who will be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter will be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nJeter, 43, retired after 20 seasons as the Yankees' shortstop. A 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nNow the question is whether Jeter can help the Marlins win.\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since 2003, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n-- -- --\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York and AP freelance writer Chris Stock in Miami contributed to this report.\n\n-- -- --\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\n-- -- --\n\nFollow Steven Wine on Twitter: http://twitter.com/Steve -- Wine", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T06:05:00Z", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "source": {"uri": "staradvertiser.com", "title": "Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "id": "872"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:05:00", "url": "http://www.staradvertiser.com/2017/08/11/sports/sports-breaking/ap-source-marlins-plan-to-sell-to-group-that-includes-jeter/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8750310", "image": "http://www.staradvertiser.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/web1_5777737-bfa87745878645d088dec19a75a48dde-300x191.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "06:05:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Jeter and the wealthy venture capitalist.\n\nPer the report, Jeter will handle the baseball side of the organization, while Sherman will be the \"control\" person.\n\nFrom the report:\n\nMiami Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the franchise for $1.2 billion to a group led by New York businessman Bruce Sherman and former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, and Major League Baseball is expected to receive the written agreement on Friday, according to a New York based MLB source.\n\nThe Sherman/Jeter group has about 16 investors and they have raised the money to purchase the team after months of seeking investors to meet Loria's asking price, the source said.\n\nThe Sherman/Jeter group has 16 total investors, while Jeter is reportedly shelling out $25 million of his own for the project.\n\nThe Marlins are expected to lose more than $60 million this season. The team's TV contracts pays the lowest of any team in MLB, and Marlins attendance traditionally ranks among the bottom five in MLB, according to the report from the Miami Herald.\n\nIt will be an uphill battle for Jeter and company to turn around a team that hasn't been to the playoffs since the team won the 2003 World Series.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:04:00Z", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "source": {"uri": "thespun.com", "title": "The Spun", "id": "16928"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:20:00", "url": "http://thespun.com/more/mlb/report-miami-marlins-owner-jeffrey-loria-sells-marlins-to-group-led-by-derek-jeter", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8742292", "image": "http://thespun-xt0mxgicgroc.stackpathdns.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/marlins-park.png", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:04:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bud Black"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bud_Black", "score": 2, "id": "742618", "type": "person"}], "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Derek Jeter wins again.\n\nThe Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes the former New York Yankees captain, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented.\n\nThe Marlins' months-long sale saga included many twists before owner Jeffrey Loria settled on the popular Jeter, who led the Yankees to five World Series championships before retiring after the 2014 season.\n\nThe person speaking on condition of anonymity said MLB was told Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who will be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter will be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nJeter, 43, retired after 20 seasons as the Yankees' shortstop. A 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nNow the question is whether Jeter can help the Marlins win.\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since 2003, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n-- -- --\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York and AP freelance writer Chris Stock in Miami contributed to this report.\n\n-- -- --\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\n-- -- --\n\nFollow Steven Wine on Twitter: http://twitter.com/Steve -- Wine", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:07:00Z", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "source": {"uri": "nwitimes.com", "title": "nwi.com", "id": "1472"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:07:00", "url": "http://www.nwitimes.com/news/national/ap-source-marlins-plan-to-sell-to-group-that-includes/article_bc2368f7-d4d1-528a-a426-c9c20b20a4f9.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8727706", "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/nwitimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/b7/fb7e33a2-3cb2-5fec-948d-5a22d3b6f76a/598d18ea05971.image.jpg?crop=512%2C288%2C0%2C37&resize=512%2C288&order=crop%2Cresize", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:07:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Friday, March 13, 2015, is part of a group attempting to buy the Miami Marlins.\n\nBy Steven Wine, Associated Press\n\nFriday, Aug. 11, 2017 | 5:30 p.m.\n\nMIAMI (AP) -- Derek Jeter wins again.\n\nThe Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes the former New York Yankees captain, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented.\n\nThe Marlins' months-long sale saga included many twists before owner Jeffrey Loria settled on the popular Jeter, who led the Yankees to five World Series championships before retiring after the 2014 season.\n\nThe person speaking on condition of anonymity said MLB was told Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who will be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter will be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nJeter, 43, retired after 20 seasons as the Yankees' shortstop. A 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nNow the question is whether Jeter can help the Marlins win.\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since 2003, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. "Miami"}, "type": "loc", "score": 5, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Miami"}, "type": "place", "country": {"label": {"eng": "United States of America"}, "type": "country"}}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami", "id": "182034"}, {"label": {"eng": "New York"}, "type": "loc", "score": 5, "location": {"label": {"eng": "New York"}, "type": "place", "country": {"label": Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 5, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}], "body": "According to a report from The Miami Herald, the Jeter-led group has won the bidding to purchase the Miami Marlins from Jeffrey Loria.\n\nMiami Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the franchise for $1.2 billion to a group led by New York businessman Bruce Sherman and former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, and Major League Baseball is expected to receive the written agreement on Friday, according to a New York based MLB source.\n\nAs for the little-known Sherman? The report projects him to be something close to a managing general partner.\n\nJeter is expected to run both the baseball and business side of the Marlins.\n\nThe final sale is expected to be completed on Friday, and includes a slew of investors along with Sherman and Jeter.\n\nA purchase agreement with the Sherman/Jeter group, which has been worked on for months, is expected to be completed on Friday and submitted to MLB offices in New York.\n\nDespite making hundreds of millions during a decorated career in pinstripes, Jeter reportedly isn't putting up a big stake to earn such a big role in the Marlins.\n\nJeter is believed to be contributing only $25 million of his own money but has a great relationship with Sherman, who will allow Jeter to essentially run the organization.\n\nIt will take a MLB vote to approve of the Jeter-Sherman pairing and official sale of the team.\n\n\"He brings that winning mentality,\" Posada said. \"The people in Miami want it. They want change. I think the Marlins, if it happens ... it will be a great move for not only the organization, but I think for the city.\"\n\nNow the city of Miami and the franchise can experience Jeter steering the ship.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:52:00Z", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "source": {"uri": "nj.com", "title": "NJ.com (New Jersey)", "id": "144"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:12:00", "url": "http://www.nj.com/yankees/index.ssf/2017/08/yankees_legend_derek_jeter_wins_bid_to_buy_miami_m.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8717109", "image": "http://image.nj.com/home/njo-media/width620/img/njcom_photos/photo/2017/05/14/22691831-large.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:52:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bud Black"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bud_Black", "score": 2, "id": "742618", "type": "person"}], "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Derek Jeter wins again.\n\nThe Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes the former New York Yankees captain, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented.\n\nThe Marlins' months-long sale saga included many twists before owner Jeffrey Loria settled on the popular Jeter, who led the Yankees to five World Series championships before retiring after the 2014 season.\n\nThe person speaking on condition of anonymity said MLB was told Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who will be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter will be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\n''It will be an honor to play for a future Hall of Famer,'' Marlins outfielder Marcell Ozuna said in Spanish after Friday night's win over the Colorado Rockies. ''Hopefully he will bring harmony and winning tradition we have been accustomed of him.''\n\nThe Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nJeter, 43, retired after 20 seasons as the Yankees' shortstop. A 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n''Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,'' Mattingly said before Friday night's game. ''What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.''\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n''I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game - that's the main thing,'' Black said. ''A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.''\n\nNow the question is whether Jeter can help the Marlins win.\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since 2003, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a ''confluence of events'' prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n---\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York and AP freelance writers Chris Stock and Santos Perez in Miami contributed to this report.\n\n---\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\n---\n\nFollow Steven Wine on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Steve-Wine", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T22:04:00Z", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "title": "Yahoo Sports", "id": "2139"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:20:00", "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/ap-source-marlins-plan-sell-group-includes-jeter-225944736--mlb.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8742287", "image": "https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/B_LKKjy4E26xUdT1.YeFeQ--/aD0zNTYxO3c9NDQxNTtzbT0xO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/Sports/ap/201707120659251599554", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "22:04:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

{"location": null, "categories": [{"label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Amateur", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Amateur", "wgt": 100, "id": 36}, {"label": "dmoz/Science/Biology/Flora and Fauna", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Biology/Flora_and_Fauna", "wgt": 100, "id": 93}, {"label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "wgt": 100, "id": 220}, {"label": "742618", "type": "person"}], "body": "Former New York Yankees player Derek Jeter waves to fans during a ceremony retiring his number at Yankee Stadium on May 14, 2017, in New York.\n\nThe Miami Marlins told MLB they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes the former New York Yankees captain, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented.\n\nThe Marlins' monthslong sale saga included many twists before owner Jeffrey Loria settled on the popular Jeter, who led the Yankees to five World Series championships before retiring after the 2014 season.\n\nThe person speaking on condition of anonymity said MLB was told Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who will be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Fla.\n\nJeter will be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nJeter, 43, retired after 20 seasons as the Yankees' shortstop. A 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nNow the question is whether Jeter can help the Marlins win.\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since 2003, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-05-14", "textEnd": 128, "textStart": 116}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:44:00Z", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "source": {"uri": "triblive.com", "title": "TribLIVE", "id": "1994"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:44:00", "url": "http://triblive.com/sports/mlb/12612374-74/ap-source-marlins-plan-to-sell-to-group-that-includes-derek-jeter", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8730755", "image": "http://triblive.com/csp/mediapool/sites/dt.common.streams.StreamServer.cls?STREAMOID=8m81JyVM3GBGNWteBIz7tM$daE2N3K4ZzOUsqbU5sYsiF$1jAXa0MpLbqDDqXqL$WCsjLu883Ygn4B49Lvm9bPe2QeMKQdVeZmXF$9l$4uCZ8QDXhaHEp3rvzXRJFdy0KqPHLoMevcTLo3h8xh70Y6N_U_CryOsw6FTOdKL_jpQ-&CONTENTTYPE=image/jpeg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:44:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commissioner_of_Baseball", "score": 3, "id": "386682", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Marcell Ozuna"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcell_Ozuna", "score": Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bud Black"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bud_Black", "score": 2, "id": "742618", "type": "person"}], "body": "The Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes the former New York Yankees captain, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented.\n\nThe Marlins' months-long sale saga included many twists before owner Jeffrey Loria settled on the popular Jeter, who led the Yankees to five World Series championships before retiring after the 2014 season.\n\nThe person speaking on condition of anonymity said MLB was told Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who will be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter will be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\n\"It will be an honor to play for a future Hall of Famer,\" Marlins outfielder Marcell Ozuna said in Spanish after Friday night's win over the Colorado Rockies. \"Hopefully he will bring harmony and winning tradition we have been accustomed of him.\"\n\nThe Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nJeter, 43, retired after 20 seasons as the Yankees' shortstop. A 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nNow the question is whether Jeter can help the Marlins win.\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since 2003, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n___\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York and AP freelance writers Chris Stock and Santos Perez in Miami contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T04:23:00Z", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "source": {"uri": "miamiherald.com", "title": "Miami Herald", "id": "283"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:23:00", "url": "http://www.miamiherald.com/news/business/article166827177.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8742509", "image": "http://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/4bn88g/picture166625307/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/Marlins_Nationals_Baseball_15214.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "04:23:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

2, "id": "742618", "type": "person"}], "body": "CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST\n\nMIAMI, Fla. -- Derek Jeter wins again.\n\nThe Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes the former New York Yankees captain, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented.\n\nThe Marlins' months-long sale saga included many twists before owner Jeffrey Loria settled on the popular Jeter, who led the Yankees to five World Series championships before retiring after the 2014 season.\n\nThe person speaking on condition of anonymity said MLB was told Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who will be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter will be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\n\"It will be an honor to play for a future Hall of Famer,\" Marlins outfielder Marcell Ozuna said in Spanish after Friday night's win over the Colorado Rockies. \"Hopefully he will bring harmony and winning tradition we have been accustomed of him.\"\n\nThe Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nJeter, 43, retired after 20 seasons as the Yankees' shortstop. A 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nNow the question is whether Jeter can help the Marlins win.\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since 2003, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n\u00a9 2017 Associated Press\n\nCONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T14:01:00Z", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "source": {"uri": "firstcoastnews.com", "title": "WTLV", "id": "4995"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:01:00", "url": "http://www.firstcoastnews.com/sports/baseball/ap-source-marlins-plan-to-sell-to-group-that-includes-jeter/463861888", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8800958", "image": "http://content.firstcoastnews.com/photo/2017/08/12/JeterDerek_AP_1502544902818_10242734_ver1.0.jpeg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "14:01:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"score": 2, "id": "334719", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Commissioner of Baseball"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commissioner_of_Baseball", "score": 3, "id": "386682", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rob Manfred"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rob_Manfred", "score": 3, "id": "430558", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bud Black"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bud_Black", "score": 2, "id": "742618", "type": "person"}], "body": "The Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes the former New York Yankees captain, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented.\n\nThe Marlins' months-long sale saga included many twists before owner Jeffrey Loria settled on the popular Jeter, who led the Yankees to five World Series championships before retiring after the 2014 season.\n\nThe person speaking on condition of anonymity said MLB was told Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who will be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter will be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nJeter, 43, retired after 20 seasons as the Yankees' shortstop. A 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nNow the question is whether Jeter can help the Marlins win.\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since 2003, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n___\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York and AP freelance writer Chris Stock in Miami contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T00:17:00Z", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "source": {"uri": "newsobserver.com", "title": "The News&Observer", "id": "8851"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:17:00", "url": "http://www.newsobserver.com/news/business/article166827177.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8723500", "image": "http://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/4bn88g/picture166625307/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/Marlins_Nationals_Baseball_15214.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "00:17:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_World_Series", "score": 2, "id": "742691", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Miami -- The Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented publicly.\n\nThe person said MLB was told owner Jeffrey Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who would be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Fla.\n\nJeter would be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Sherman-Jeter group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nJeter, 43, retired in 2014 after 20 seasons with Yankees. The shortstop and team captain played on five World Series championship teams -- and on the Yankees club that lost to the Marlins in the 2003 World Series.\n\nA 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since winning the 2003 title, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. "score": 2, "id": "334719", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Commissioner of Baseball"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commissioner_of_Baseball", "score": 3, "id": "386682", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rob Manfred"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rob_Manfred", "score": 3, "id": "430558", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bud Black"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bud_Black", "score": 2, "id": "742618", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "2003 World Series"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_World_Series", "score": 2, "id": "742691", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MIAMI -- The Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented publicly.\n\nThe person said MLB was told owner Jeffrey Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who would be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter would be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Sherman-Jeter group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 per cent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nJeter, 43, retired in 2014 after 20 seasons with Yankees. The shortstop and team captain played on five World Series championship teams -- and on the Yankees club that lost to the Marlins in the 2003 World Series.\n\nA 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the post-season since winning the 2003 title, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T00:39:00Z", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "source": {"uri": "edmontonsun.com", "title": "Edmonton Sun", "id": "1063"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:39:00", "url": "http://www.edmontonsun.com/2017/08/11/marlins-plan-to-sell-to-group-that-includes-jeter?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=recommend-button&utm_campaign=Marlins plan to sell to group that includes Jeter", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8725483", "image": "http://storage.edmontonsun.com/v1/suns-prod-images/1297981796687_LARGE_BOX.jpg?quality=80&stmp=1502496298259", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "00:39:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"310097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Miami Marlins"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Marlins", "score": 5, "id": "310673", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Gentlemen's "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 5, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of African-American firsts"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Florida", "score": 3, "id": "1366586", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Jeter and Sherman reportedly have an agreement to purchase the Marlins from Jeffrey Loria\n\nOnce again, Miami Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has an agreement in place to sell the franchise to an ownership group that includes Derek Jeter. Jeter and New York venture capitalist Bruce Sherman have reportedly agreed to purchase the club for $1.2 billion. The Marlins and Loria have not confirmed the agreement.\n\nLoria, who is regarded by many as the worst owner in baseball (if not all of sports), has been looking to sell the Marlins for months now. Not surprisingly, it's not until after last month's All-Star Game that a firm sale agreement is in place. Loria reaped all the All-Star Game revenue and now will sell the team. It's what any smart businessman would have done.\n\nHere are seven things to know about the reported sale of the Marlins to the Sherman-Jeter group.\n\n1. The sale is not yet final\n\nThis is important to note, because this is not the first time Jeter has come close to purchasing the Marlins. He and former Florida governor Jeb Bush won the team at auction earlier this year, though they were unable to finalize the sale because they couldn't raise the money. Also, Loria reportedly had a handshake agreement in place to sell the team to a different ownership group over the winter, but that fell apart due to political reasons.\n\nLoria and the Sherman-Jeter group have a sale agreement in place and the money has already been raised. The next step is getting approval from MLB and the other 29 owners. That won't happen for weeks, if not months. That doesn't mean the sale is in danger or anything like that. It just means Loria, Sherman, and Jeter have to wait until the next quarterly owners meetings to get approval. That can take some time.\n\n2. Jeter is not the 'control person'\n\nAccording to Barry Jackson of the Miami Herald, Jeter is putting only $25 million of his own money into that $1.2 billion purchase price, so he is a minority owner. He will not be the \"control person,\" but he will run the business and baseball operations.\n\nFrom Jackson:\n\nSherman, a wealthy venture capitalist who has a home in New York and is building a home in South Florida, will be the \"control person,\" similar to a managing general partner.\n\nBut Jeter, the former New York Yankees star shortstop, will run the business and baseball sides of the organization, the source said.\n\n...\n\nJeter is believed to be contributing only $25 million of his own money but has a great relationship with Sherman, who will allow Jeter to essentially run the organization.\n\nAlso, Jeter brings unmatched star power and name recognition to the table. He is one of the most popular athletes in the world and that will only enhance the team's brand.\n\n3. Michael Jordan is involved too\n\nAs is often the case, the Sherman-Jeter ownership group includes many small investors. Jeter is, technically, one of those small investors. Another is basketball great Michael Jordan.\n\nFrom Jon Heyman of FanRag Sports:\n\nBeyond Sherman, most of the other members of Jeter's group are smaller investments, with $5 million, $10 million and $20 million increments. Basketball superstar Michael Jordan is mostly lending his name, and is believed to be contributing no more than a few million dollars, if that.\n\nOwning a baseball team is very lucrative -- the revenue sharing system essentially guarantees you'll make money -- so it's not a surprise Jordan and others want a piece of the pie. It's a great investment.\n\n4. Jeter is making history\n\nEven though he's not the \"control person,\" Jeter will be the first African-American to hold his position:\n\nBaseball still has a diversity problem, especially at the front office and ownership level. Surely MLB is hoping Jeter helps spark more diversity hires at upper level positions.\n\n5. The front office is expected to remain in place ...\n\nOnce the sale is final, massive changes are not coming to the Marlins. Several senior level executives are expected to remain in place.\n\nMarlins fans hoping for sweeping change as soon as Loria is out of the picture are likely to be disappointed.\n\n6. ... for now\n\nThat all said, it is very common for new ownership groups to take some time to evaluate the state of the team before making any changes. The Dodgers were sold in March 2012 and it wasn't until October 2014 that the club hired Andrew Friedman away from the Rays to run their baseball operations. These things take time.\n\nNow, just because it took the Dodgers three seasons to change their front office after being sold does not mean the Sherman-Jeter group will wait three seasons to make changes either. They could come in and quickly decide a change in direction is needed. Samson and Hill are staying on, though that should not be considered permanent. At some point the Sherman-Jeter group will want to bring in their own people to run the show.\n\n7. The sale price is the second highest in MLB history\n\nThink the other 29 MLB owners are happy? The reportedly $1.2 billion sale price will be the second largest sum ever paid for a big-league franchise, behind the $2 billion the Guggenheim Partners paid for the Dodgers in March 2012. The Marlins are said to be bleeding money -- they're reportedly going to lose $60 million this year -- yet the franchise is still insanely valuable. If the Marlins are selling for $1.2 billion, imagine what some of the other franchises could fetch.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-03-", "textEnd": 4288, "textStart": 4278, "freq": 2}, {"amb": false, "date": "2014-10-", "textEnd": 4321, "textStart": 4309}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T23:46:00Z", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "title": "CBS Sports", "id": "765"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:46:00", "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/marlins-sale-derek-jeter-bruce-sherman-michael-jordan-and-more-things-to-know/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8720587", "image": "https://sportshub.cbsistatic.com/i/r/2017/08/11/b700a65c-08ec-42cd-817a-dd88dd21fcba/thumbnail/770x433/cb24a637016effd90e30882a8e8f68df/usatsi-10058040.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "23:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_World_Series", "score": 2, "id": "742691", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- The Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented publicly.\n\nThe person said MLB was told owner Jeffrey Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who would be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter would be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Sherman-Jeter group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nJeter, 43, retired in 2014 after 20 seasons with Yankees. The shortstop and team captain played on five World Series championship teams -- and on the Yankees club that lost to the Marlins in the 2003 World Series.\n\nA 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since winning the 2003 title, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n-- -- --\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York and AP freelancer Chris Stock in Miami contributed to this report.\n\n-- -- --\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\n-- -- --\n\nFollow Steven Wine on Twitter: http://twitter.com/Steve -- Wine", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T00:14:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"uri": "postbulletin.com", "title": "PostBulletin.com", "id": "3887"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:14:00", "url": "http://www.postbulletin.com/business/ap-source-marlins-plan-to-sell-to-group-that-includes/article_338b8c5d-3e0a-5f70-9331-f60590dd32cb.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8723258", "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/postbulletin.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/7/85/7852b121-58fc-5593-9cf4-ef8c241f668e/598e469e4b017.image.jpg?crop=435%2C326%2C38%2C0&resize=435%2C326&order=crop%2Cresize", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "00:14:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bear_Stearns", "score": 2, "id": "393827", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Hank Aaron"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hank_Aaron", "score": 2, "id": "413288", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 4, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}], "body": "Miami Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the franchise for $1.2 billion to a group led by New York businessman Bruce Sherman and former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, and Major League Baseball is expected to receive the written agreement on Friday, according to a New York based MLB source.\n\nSherman, 69, a wealthy venture capitalist who has a home in New York and is building a home in South Florida, will be the \"control person,\" similar to a managing general partner.\n\nBut Jeter, the former New York Yankees star shortstop, will run the business and baseball sides of the organization, the source said.\n\nThe Sherman/Jeter group has about 16 investors and they have raised the money to purchase the team after months of seeking investors to meet Loria's asking price, the source said.\n\nAmong the other investors: former NBA star Michael Jordan, who's a friend of Jeter.\n\nA purchase agreement with the Sherman/Jeter group, which has been worked on for months, is expected to be completed on Friday and submitted to MLB offices in New York.\n\nSherman, a Marlins fan, is known for his philanthropic work and previously was the chairman and chief investment officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nSherman increased his investment in the Marlins bid after wealthy Chicago businessman Richard Chaifetz backed out of the deal.\n\nJeter is believed to be contributing only $25 million of his own money but has a great relationship with Sherman, who will allow Jeter to essentially run the organization.\n\nMLB officials are expected to discuss the sale, but not vote on it, in owners meetings in Chicago next week. Sherman and possibly Jeter are expected to meet with the ownership committee prior for a full vote of owners, which is the final required step for the sale's completion.\n\nThe vote could be weeks away, with closing expected the first week of October.\n\nMiami businessman Jorge Mas also pursued the team and met with Marlins officials this week but did not match the $1.2 billion bid of the Sherman and Jeter group.\n\nNew York businessman Wayne Rothbaum, who led a competing group that included former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, also bid for the Marlins, before stopping his pursuit earlier this week.\n\nLoria has owned the team since 2002 and won a World Series in 2003, but the Marlins haven't made the playoffs since then, the second-longest postseason drought in Major League Baseball behind the Seattle Mariners.\n\nThe Marlins are expected to lose more than $60 million this season, according to a source who has seen their books, in part because their revenues are among the lowest in MLB and in part because their $115 million payroll is the largest in franchise history.\n\nThe Marlins' TV contracts pays the lowest of any team in MLB, and Marlins attendance traditionally ranks among the bottom five in MLB.\n\nLoria decided to sell the team for personal reasons and had been seeking a buyer for months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson on Friday declined to comment about where the sales process stood.\n\nBusinessobserver.com refers to Sherman as \"the shrewd Naples investor who posted spectacular investment returns for years before the financial crisis and a bet on Bear Stearns blemished an otherwise stellar track record. Sherman's investing style is to select companies he thinks are undervalued.\"\n\nJeter, meanwhile, would give the Marlins cachet and a former player universally respected in baseball.\n\nJeter, 42, played his entire 20-year career with the Yankees before retiring after the 2014 season and was one of the most celebrated, heavily marketed and distinguished players of his era.\n\nHe was a 14-time All-Star, won five Gold Glove Awards, five Silver Slugger awards, two Hank Aaron Awards and is the Yankees' all-time career leader in hits (3,465), doubles (544), games played (2,747), stolen bases (358), times on base (4,716) and at-bats (11,195).\n\nJeter became the 28th player to reach 3,000 hits and finished his career sixth all-time in career hits and the all-time MLB leader in hits by a shortstop.\n\nHe consistently ranked among the American League leaders in hits and runs scored for most of his career, and served as the Yankees' team captain from 2003 until his retirement in 2014.\n\nJeter won five World Series (1996, 1998 through 2000 and 2009) and holds many postseason records.\n\nOther confirmed investors in the Sherman/Jeter group, besides NBA legend Jordan (who owns the NBA's Charlotte Hornets), include former Morgan Stanley wealth management chief Greg Fleming, who helped put together the bid for Sherman and Jeter; Doug Kimmelman, a former Goldman Sachs executive who founded Energy Capital Partners and John Troiano, managing Partner and Co-Founder of financial firm TBG Investments, which advises customers on investments.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {"liCnt": 42}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:52:00Z", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "source": {"uri": "miamiherald.com", "title": "Miami Herald", "id": "283"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:12:00", "url": "http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mlb/miami-marlins/article166767852.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8717115", "image": "http://www.miamiherald.com/latest-news/6gvcvt-Jeter.jpg/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/Jeter.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:52:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

a group featuring former New York Yankees captain Derek Jeter, a person familiar with the deal said Saturday.\n\nThe person confirmed the Friday night signing to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the Marlins have not confirmed the agreement.\n\nAnother person familiar with the agreement said Friday that Jeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman. That person said Major League Baseball was told that Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria will receive about $1.2 billion from the Jeter-Sherman group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman, who will be the controlling owner, spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida. Jeter, a 14-time All-Star who retired after the 2014 season, will be in charge of baseball operations.\n\nMLB owners will discuss the deal at their meeting next week in Chicago.
