"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hank_Aaron", "score": 1, "id": "413288", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 4, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Governors of Florida"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Florida", "score": 2, "id": "1366586", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Miami Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the franchise for $1.2 billion to a group led by New York businessman Bruce Sherman and former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, and Major League Baseball is expected to receive the written agreement on Friday, according to a New York-based MLB source.\n\nSherman, a wealthy venture capitalist who has a home in New York and is building a home in South Florida, will be the \"control person,\" similar to a managing general partner.\n\nBut Jeter, the former New York Yankees star shortstop, will run the business and baseball sides of the organization, the source said.\n\nThe Sherman/Jeter group has about 16 investors and they have raised the money to purchase the team after months of seeking investors to meet Loria's asking price, the source said.\n\nA purchase agreement with the Sherman/Jeter group, which has been worked on for months, is expected to be completed on Friday and submitted to MLB offices in New York.\n\nSherman, a Marlins fan, is known for his philanthropic work and previously was the chairman and chief investment officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nSherman increased his investment in the Marlins bid after wealthy Chicago businessman Richard Chaifetz backed out of the deal.\n\nJeter is believed to be contributing only $25 million of his own money but has a great relationship with Sherman, who will allow Jeter to essentially run the organization.\n\nMLB officials are expected to discuss the sale, but not vote on it, in owners meetings in Chicago next week. Sherman and possibly Jeter are expected to meet with the ownership committee prior for a full vote of owners, which is the final required step for the sale's completion.\n\nThe vote could be weeks away, with closing expected the first week of October.\n\nMiami businessman Jorge Mas also pursued the team and met with Marlins officials this week but did not match the $1.2 billion bid of the Sherman and Jeter group.\n\nNew York businessman Wayne Rothbaum, who led a competing group that included former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, also bid for the Marlins, before stopping his pursuit earlier this week.\n\nLoria has owned the team since 2002 and won a World Series in 2003, but the Marlins haven't made the playoffs since then, the second-longest postseason drought in Major League Baseball behind the Seattle Mariners.\n\nThe Marlins are expected to lose more than $60 million this season, according to a source who has seen their books, in part because their revenues are among the lowest in MLB and in part because their $115 million payroll is the largest in franchise history.\n\nThe Marlins' TV contracts pays the lowest of any team in MLB, and Marlins attendance traditionally ranks among the bottom five in MLB.\n\nLoria decided to sell the team for personal reasons and had been seeking a buyer for months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson on Friday declined to comment about where the sales process stood.\n\nBusinessobserver.com refers to Sherman as \"the shrewd Naples investor who posted spectacular investment returns for years before the financial crisis and a bet on Bear Stearns blemished an otherwise stellar track record. Sherman's investing style is to select companies he thinks are undervalued.\"\n\nJeter, meanwhile, would give the Marlins cachet and a former player universally respected in baseball.\n\nJeter, 42, played his entire 20-year career with the Yankees before retiring after the 2014 season and was one of the most celebrated, heavily marketed and distinguished players of his era.\n\nHe was a 14-time All-Star, won five Gold Glove Awards, five Silver Slugger awards, two Hank Aaron Awards and is the Yankees' all-time career leader in hits (3,465), doubles (544), games played (2,747), stolen bases (358), times on base (4,716) and at-bats (11,195).\n\nJeter became the 28th player to reach 3,000 hits and finished his career sixth all-time in career hits and the all-time MLB leader in hits by a shortstop.\n\nHe consistently ranked among the American League leaders in hits and runs scored for most of his career, and served as the Yankees' team captain from 2003 until his retirement in 2014.\n\nJeter won five World Series (1996, 1998 through 2000 and 2009) and holds many postseason records.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:26:00Z", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "source": {"uri": "norwichbulletin.com", "title": "The Bulletin", "id": "593"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:26:00", "url": "http://www.norwichbulletin.com/sports/20170811/sources-derek-jeter-backed-group-agrees-to-buy-marlins?rssfeed=true", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8729405", "image": "http://www.norwichbulletin.com/storyimage/CT/20170811/SPORTS/170819878/AR/0/AR-170819878.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:26:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"body": "Miami Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the franchise for $1.2 billion to a group led by New York businessman Bruce Sherman and former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, and Major League Baseball is expected to receive the written agreement on Friday, according to a New York based MLB source.\n\nSherman, a wealthy venture capitalist who has a home in New York and is building a home in South Florida, will be the \"control person,\" similar to a managing general partner.\n\nBut Jeter, the former New York Yankees star shortstop, will run the business and baseball sides of the organization, the source said.\n\nThe Sherman/Jeter group has about 16 investors and they have raised the money to purchase the team after months of seeking investors to meet Loria's asking price, the source said.\n\nA purchase agreement with the Sherman/Jeter group, which has been worked on for months, is expected to be completed on Friday and submitted to MLB offices in New York.\n\nSherman, a Marlins fan, is known for his philanthropic work and previously was the chairman and chief investment officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nSherman increased his investment in the Marlins bid after wealthy Chicago businessman Richard Chaifetz backed out of the deal.\n\nJeter is believed to be contributing only $25 million of his own money but has a great relationship with Sherman, who will allow Jeter to essentially run the organization.\n\nMLB officials are expected to discuss the sale, but not vote on it, in owners meetings in Chicago next week. Sherman and possibly Jeter are expected to meet with the ownership committee prior for a full vote of owners, which is the final required step for the sale's completion.\n\nThe vote could be weeks away, with closing expected the first week of October.\n\nMiami businessman Jorge Mas also pursued the team and met with Marlins officials this week but did not match the $1.2 billion bid of the Sherman and Jeter group.\n\nNew York businessman Wayne Rothbaum, who led a competing group that included former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, also bid for the Marlins, before stopping his pursuit earlier this week.\n\nLoria has owned the team since 2002 and won a World Series in 2003, but the Marlins haven't made the playoffs since then, the second-longest postseason drought in Major League Baseball behind the Seattle Mariners.\n\nThe Marlins are expected to lose more than $60 million this season, according to a source who has seen their books, in part because their revenues are among the lowest in MLB and in part because their $115 million payroll is the largest in franchise history.\n\nThe Marlins' TV contracts pays the lowest of any team in MLB, and Marlins attendance traditionally ranks among the bottom five in MLB.\n\nLoria decided to sell the team for personal reasons and had been seeking a buyer for months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson on Friday declined to comment about where the sales process stood.\n\nBusinessobserver.com refers to Sherman as \"the shrewd Naples investor who posted spectacular investment returns for years before the financial crisis and a bet on Bear Stearns blemished an otherwise stellar track record. Sherman's investing style is to select companies he thinks are undervalued.\"\n\nJeter, meanwhile, would give the Marlins cachet and a former player universally respected in baseball.\n\nJeter, 42, played his entire 20-year career with the Yankees before retiring after the 2014 season and was one of the most celebrated, heavily marketed and distinguished players of his era.\n\nHe was a 14-time All-Star, won five Gold Glove Awards, five Silver Slugger awards, two Hank Aaron Awards and is the Yankees' all-time career leader in hits (3,465), doubles (544), games played (2,747), stolen bases (358), times on base (4,716) and at-bats (11,195).\n\nJeter became the 28th player to reach 3,000 hits and finished his career sixth all-time in career hits and the all-time MLB leader in hits by a shortstop.\n\nHe consistently ranked among the American League leaders in hits and runs scored for most of his career, and served as the Yankees' team captain from 2003 until his retirement in 2014.\n\nJeter won five World Series (1996, 1998 through 2000 and 2009) and holds many postseason records.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "source": {"uri": "heraldnet.com", "title": "HeraldNet.com", "id": "10395"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:28:00", "url": "http://www.heraldnet.com/sports/source-jeters-ownership-group-to-by-marlins-for-1-2-billion/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8729643", "image": "http://www.heraldnet.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/heraldnet_logo.png", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_World_Series", "score": 2, "id": "742691", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- The Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented publicly.\n\nThe person said MLB was told owner Jeffrey Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who would be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter would be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Sherman-Jeter group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nJeter, 43, retired in 2014 after 20 seasons with Yankees. The shortstop and team captain played on five World Series championship teams - and on the Yankees club that lost to the Marlins in the 2003 World Series.\n\nA 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game - that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since winning the 2003 title, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n---\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York and AP freelancer Chris Stock in Miami contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T23:40:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "title": "Associated Press", "id": "963"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:45:00", "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/B/BBN_MARLINS_SALE_FLOL-?SITE=ORCOO&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8720538", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "23:40:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sponsored_Content_(South_Park)", "score": 3, "id": "1283290", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- The Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented publicly.\n\nThe person said MLB was told owner Jeffrey Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who would be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nSponsored Content: How is your agency managing and maximizing its data? Share your opinions in a Federal News Radio survey.\n\nJeter would be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Sherman-Jeter group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nSEC warns TSP participants of new scam\n\nJeter, 43, retired in 2014 after 20 seasons with Yankees. The shortstop and team captain played on five World Series championship teams -- and on the Yankees club that lost to the Marlins in the 2003 World Series.\n\nA 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since winning the 2003 title, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n___\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York and AP freelancer Chris Stock in Miami contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\n___\n\nFollow Steven Wine on Twitter: http://twitter.com/Steve_Wine", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T23:53:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"uri": "federalnewsradio.com", "title": "Federal News Radio", "id": "9518"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:53:00", "url": "https://federalnewsradio.com/sports-news/2017/08/ap-source-marlins-plan-to-sell-to-group-that-includes-jeter/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8721349", "image": "https://federalnewsradio.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Marlins_Nationals_Baseball_15214.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "23:53:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Samson (baseball)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Samson_(baseball)", "score": 1, "id": "828953", "type": "person"}], "body": "The Miami Marlins sale saga has its next chapter, and maybe a conclusion.\n\nOwner Jeffrey Loria agreed Friday to sell the team for $1.2 billion to a group headed by New York businessman Bruce Sherman and highlighted by New York Yankees legend Derek Jeter, according to multiple reports.\n\nThe deal is not final yet, and likely won't be for months. It will need approval from 21 of the other 29 major league team owners.\n\nThe Marlins and Major League Baseball, through spokespeople, declined to comment.\n\nA purchase agreement was expected to be submitted to MLB on Friday, according to the Miami Herald. Fox Business reported that Loria and Sherman/Jeter have a \"handshake deal.\" In April, Loria reached an agreement in principle with a group including Jeter and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, but that deal was not completed.\n\nSherman, 69, will be the new ownership group's control person, while Jeter, 43, will run the business and baseball operations departments, the Herald reported. Jeter is said to be investing only $25 million of his own money.\n\nThe Sherman/Jeter group beat out South Florida billionaire Jorge Mas, who bid a reported $1.17 billion. A third group, led by Quague Capital founder Wayne Rothbaum and Bush, had been quieter over the past month-plus and reportedly dropped out of the running completely this week.\n\nJeter, who lives in Tampa, has long expressed a desire to own a major league team, but that his group is so close to winning is something of an underdog story. He has been involved with the bidding since the process began, but his ever-shifting group of investors has been hit by key defections, including that of Chicago billionaire Richard Chaifetz last month and Bush in late May.\n\nJeter's group is comprised of 16 investors, including NBA legend and Charlotte Hornets owner Michael Jordan, according to the Herald. Jordan and Jeter have been friends\n\nSherman previously headed the Naples-based Private Capital Management. He retired in 2009.\n\nJeter won five World Series championships in his 20 years playing shortstop for the Yankees. He was briefly teammates with and then coached by current Marlins manager Don Mattingly.\n\nOn Friday at Marlins Park, Mattingly spoke glowingly but in generalities about Jeter.\n\n\"Derek has been successful in everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said. \"Good people with the kind of ability that he had as a player, that translates into business just like it does just like it does to anything else. I think that foundation, hard work, determination, confidence, all those things lead you to believe that Derek is going to be successful at whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nThis is brings closer to an end a soap opera that has dragged on from the early days of spring training, when club president David Samson the team was officially for sale, through the spring, when multiple other groups were reportedly closing in on buying the team, and past Miami's All-Star Game last month, when Mas seemed to emerge as a late favorite.\n\nBut all along, Loria -- known to fancy Yankees stars, including Mattingly -- seemed to favor Jeter, allowing him months to recruit the needed financial support.\n\nLoria, who previously owned the Montreal Expos, bought the Marlins for $158 million in 2002. The Marlins won the World Series in 2003, but haven't returned to the playoffs since and last had a winning season in 2009.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:40:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"uri": "orlandosentinel.com", "title": "Orlando Sentinel", "id": "883"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:40:00", "url": "http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/fl-reg-loria-agrees-to-sell-marlines-20170811-story.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8706351", "image": "http://www.trbimg.com/img-598e230b/turbine/fl-reg-loria-agrees-to-sell-marlines-20170811", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "21:40:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"score": 2, "id": "742691", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Jeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented publicly.\n\nThe person said MLB was told owner Jeffrey Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who would be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter would be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Sherman-Jeter group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson declined to comment Friday.\n\nJeter, 43, retired in 2014 after 20 seasons with Yankees. The shortstop and team captain played on five World Series championship teams - and on the Yankees club that lost to the Marlins in the 2003 World Series.\n\nA 14-time All-Star, Jeter lives in Tampa and has long talked of his desire to own a franchise. He has no front office experience.\n\nSherman is known for his philanthropic work and retired in 2009 as chief executive officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nMarlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, said he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said before Friday night's game against the Colorado Rockies. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game - that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nThe value of the Marlins has climbed dramatically even though they haven't been to the postseason since winning the 2003 title, the longest current drought in the National League, and are likely to miss the playoffs again this year. They were last in the NL in attendance 11 of the past 12 years despite a 2012 move to Marlins Park.\n\nLoria is perhaps baseball's most unpopular owner. He has long been criticized in South Florida for his frugal ways and for the ballpark deal, which was heavily subsidized with public money.\n\nHis decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest became public in April.\n\nAt the start of spring training, Samson said a \"confluence of events\" prompted Loria to put the franchise on the market. The owner was close to pitcher Jose Fernandez and badly shaken by the young ace's death in a boat crash last September.\n\n___\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York and AP freelancer Chris Stock in Miami contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\n___\n\nFollow Steven Wine on Twitter: http://twitter.com/Steve_Wine", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T00:00:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"uri": "kiro7.com", "title": "KIRO", "id": "1082"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:00:00", "url": "http://www.kiro7.com/sports/ap-source-marlins-plan-to-sell-to-group-that-includes-jeter/588927664", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8722071", "image": "https://cmgfeeds.cmgdigital.com/photo/2017/08/11/Marlins_Nationals_Baseball_15214_8834692_ver1.0_1280_720.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "00:00:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Steinbrenner", "score": 2, "id": "389806", "type": "person"}], "body": "Jeter will be a minority owner with the Marlins and figures to have a Magic Johnson-type role\n\nThe Miami Marlins are one step closer to being sold. Word got out Friday that a group led by future Hall of Famer Derek Jeter and New York venture capitalist Bruce Sherman have reached an agreement to purchase the team. The reported sale price is $1.3 billion. It should be noted the sale is not final. They still need to get approval from MLB and work out other details.\n\nAccording to Barry Jackson of the Miami Herald, Sherman will have controlling interest in the Marlins, meaning Jeter will be a minority owner. Here are some more details:\n\nSherman, a wealthy venture capitalist who has a home in New York and is building a home in South Florida, will be the \"control person,\" similar to a managing general partner.\n\nBut Jeter, the former New York Yankees star shortstop, will run the business and baseball sides of the organization, the source said.\n\nJeter, 42, made it no secret later in his playing career that he would like to one day own a team. He'll now get the opportunity to do exactly that with the Marlins even though he won't be the \"control person,\" per Jackson's report.\n\nSo the question becomes what does Jeter bring to the table as an owner? He's never owned a team before or worked in a front office, so this will all be new to him. And until you see someone out there doing it, it's impossible to know how exactly they will respond.\n\nThere is one thing Jeter will unquestionably bring the Marlins: star power and name recognition. I suppose that's two things, but you know what I mean. Jeter is one of the most recognizable athletes in the world, and while he won't be on the field daily, he will be associated with the franchise, and that is nothing but a positive for the Marlins.\n\nJeter's role figures to be very similar to Magic Johnson's role with the Dodgers. Johnson is a minority owner with the Dodgers -- the Guggenheim Partners own controlling interest in the team -- but he is essentially the face of the ownership group. He's at all the press conferences and on-field ceremonies. Why? Because, like Jeter, he is one of the most recognizable athletes in the world.\n\nIt's unclear how the Marlins will structure their front office under the Sherman-Jeter group, and that situation may not become clear for months. Jeter grew up under George Steinbrenner, the most meddlesome of owners. Will he take a similar approach with the Marlins or be more hands-off?\n\nJeter certainly knows baseball. Does he know how to evaluate talent and interpret statistical data, though? That's different than playing shortstop.\n\nAny baseball knowledge Jeter brings to the table is a plus. His main function with the Marlins will be adding legitimacy and star power to an ownership group that inevitably will be more popular than Jeffrey Loria. Loria is that despised in South Florida. Sherman may be the one calling the shots, but Jeter is the one who will be front and center representing the Marlins once the sale is final.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T23:46:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "title": "CBS Sports", "id": "765"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:46:00", "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/derek-jeter-brings-big-time-star-power-to-the-marlins-new-ownership-group/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8720592", "image": "https://sportshub.cbsistatic.com/i/r/2016/07/06/5105ccda-53b5-4e3d-b4a7-d505591f0fab/thumbnail/770x433/a318518d3a2a63f6acb599195d610565/usatsi8824951-jeter.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "23:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"548097", "type": "person"}], "body": "Miami Marlins owner Jeff Loria has reportedly accepted a $1.2 billion bid from a group led by New York Yankees legend Derek Jeter and New York businessman Bruce Sherman to buy the Marlins.\n\nAccording to the Miami Herald, Jeter will be in control of business and baseball side of the organization while Sherman, wealthy venture capitalist, will be the \"control person,\" similar to a managing general partner.\n\nIn total, the Jeter/Sherman group has approximately 16 investors, including Michael Jordan. According to the New York Post, Jordan is kicking in very little cash, but Jeter sees MJ as a role model and a mentor in how to become a successful sports executive.\n\nPer the Miami Herald,\n\n\"Other confirmed investors in the Sherman/Jeter group, besides NBA legend Jordan (who owns the NBA's Charlotte Hornets), include former Morgan Stanley wealth management chief Greg Fleming, who helped put together the bid for Sherman and Jeter; Doug Kimmelman, a former Goldman Sachs executive who founded Energy Capital Partners; John Troiano, managing Partner and Co-Founder of financial firm TBG Investments, which advises customers on investments.\"\n\nJeter has his work cut out for him in Miami, though. The Miami Herald's Barry Jackson reports that the Marlins are expected to lose over $60 million this year, have the cheapest TV contract in the league, and are routinely at the bottom of the league standings in attendance.\n\nAdditionally, the Marlins haven't made the playoffs since their World Series run in 2003, which is the second-longest streak in the MLB.\n\nExclusive: Jeffrey Loria agrees to sell Marlins to group led by Bruce Sherman and Derek Jeter. group featuring former New York Yankees captain Derek Jeter, a person familiar with the deal said Saturday.\n\nThe person confirmed the Friday night signing to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the Marlins have not confirmed the agreement.\n\nAnother person familiar with the agreement said Friday that Jeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman. That person said Major League Baseball was told that Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria will receive about $1.2 billion from the Jeter-Sherman group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman, who will be the controlling owner, spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida. Jeter, a 14-time All-Star who retired after the 2014 season, will be in charge of baseball operations.\n\nMLB owners will discuss the deal at their meeting next week in Chicago. investors that includes Yankees legend Derek Jeter has reached an agreement to purchase the Marlins for $1.2 billion. USA TODAY Sports\n\nJeffrey Loria, the soon-to-be-former owner of the Miami Marlins, has always loved the New York Yankees.\n\nIt's his favorite team.\n\nHe goes to games at Yankee Stadium.\n\nHe lives in New York.\n\nHe collects art there.\n\nHighest bidder: Jeter-led group agrees to buy Marlins for $1.2 billion\n\nAnd ever since he decided to sell the Marlins, he's always wanted the franchise to go to Derek Jeter.\n\nSo he waited.\n\nThe Jeb Bush group came and went. The Mitt Romney group disappeared. New York businessman Wayne Rothbaum bowed out. Miami businessman Jorge Mas jumped in late, but didn't come up with the money.\n\nSo Loria waited, and waited, and finally, with New York businessman Bruce Sherman joining Jeter's group, they came up with the minimum price Loria desired at $1.2 billion.\n\nThe deal was finalized Friday, a high-ranking executive with direct knowledge of the sale confirmed to USA TODAY Sports, but spoke only on the condition of anonymity, since the proposed sale has yet to be presented to Major League Baseball.\n\nSherman will be the control person. Jeter will be the baseball and business man, and everyone in the MLB offices on Park Avenue in N.Y. are ecstatic.\n\nJeter, one of the iconic names in all of baseball, with five World Series rings and a 14-time All-Star, is back in the game and immediately becomes the most famous face in baseball's ownership circles, supplanting minority owner Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Dodgers.\n\nSure, Jeter is only putting in about $25 million of his own cash.\n\nYes, Jeter has zero front office experience.\n\nAnd, yes, the team is in financial disarray, with projected losses of at least $60 million this season while the team already is in about $500 million of debt.\n\nYet, there finally is hope that the Marlins will be a valuable franchise again, knowing that whatever Jeter has touched, whether it's his Yankee teams, his brands, or even his website, has turned to gold.\n\nThe news of the sale will surely dominate the MLB owners' meetings next week in Chicago, but no vote will be taken. Sherman and Jeter still have to meet with the ownership committee, there will be a recommendation, and finally a vote.\n\nThe deal should be finalized in October, far too late to save this season, but in plenty of time to save the franchise.\n\nIt's a happy day in Florida, and throughout the game of baseball.\n\nJeter is back.\n\nAnd, just maybe, so are the Marlins.\n\nFollow Nightengale on Twitter and Facebook\n\nGALLERY: Derek Jeter; Yankees legend\n\nAutoplay\n\nShow Thumbnails\n\nShow Captions\n\nLast SlideNext Slide", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T03:48:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"uri": "standardrepublic.com", "title": "Standard Republic", "id": "18909"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:58:00", "url": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/2017/08/co-owner-derek-jeter-a-perfect-fit-to-run-the-miami-marlins/21319.htm", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8755083", "image": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/636380670485379851-USP-MLB-HOUSTON-ASTROS-AT-NEW-YORK-YANKEES-90911770.JPG", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "03:48:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Governors of Florida"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Florida", "score": 2, "id": "1366586", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Miami Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the franchise for $1.2 billion to a group led by New York businessman Bruce Sherman and former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, and Major League Baseball is expected to receive the written agreement on Friday, according to a New York based MLB source.\n\nSherman, a wealthy venture capitalist who has a home in New York and is building a home in South Florida, will be the \"control person,\" similar to a managing general partner.\n\nBut Jeter, the former New York Yankees star shortstop, will run the business and baseball sides of the organization, the source said.\n\nThe Sherman/Jeter group has about 16 investors and they have raised the money to purchase the team after months of seeking investors to meet Loria's asking price, the source said.\n\nA purchase agreement with the Sherman/Jeter group, which has been worked on for months, is expected to be completed on Friday and submitted to MLB offices in New York.\n\nSherman, a Marlins fan, is known for his philanthropic work and previously was the chairman and chief investment officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management.\n\nSherman increased his investment in the Marlins bid after wealthy Chicago businessman Richard Chaifetz backed out of the deal.\n\nJeter is believed to be contributing only $25 million of his own money but has a great relationship with Sherman, who will allow Jeter to essentially run the organization.\n\nMLB officials are expected to discuss the sale, but not vote on it, in owners meetings in Chicago next week. Sherman and possibly Jeter are expected to meet with the ownership committee prior for a full vote of owners, which is the final required step for the sale's completion.\n\nThe vote could be weeks away, with closing expected the first week of October.\n\nMiami businessman Jorge Mas also pursued the team and met with Marlins officials this week but did not match the $1.2 billion bid of the Sherman and Jeter group.\n\nNew York businessman Wayne Rothbaum, who led a competing group that included former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, also bid for the Marlins, before stopping his pursuit earlier this week.\n\nLoria has owned the team since 2002 and won a World Series in 2003, but the Marlins haven't made the playoffs since then, the second-longest postseason drought in Major League Baseball behind the Seattle Mariners.\n\nThe Marlins are expected to lose more than $60 million this season, according to a source who has seen their books, in part because their revenues are among the lowest in MLB and in part because their $115 million payroll is the largest in franchise history.\n\nThe Marlins' TV contracts pays the lowest of any team in MLB, and Marlins attendance traditionally ranks among the bottom five in MLB.\n\nLoria decided to sell the team for personal reasons and had been seeking a buyer for months.\n\nMarlins president David Samson on Friday declined to comment about where the sales process stood.\n\nBusinessobserver.com refers to Sherman as \"the shrewd Naples investor who posted spectacular investment returns for years before the financial crisis and a bet on Bear Stearns blemished an otherwise stellar track record. Sherman's investing style is to select companies he thinks are undervalued.\"\n\nJeter, meanwhile, would give the Marlins cachet and a former player universally respected in baseball.\n\nJeter, 42, played his entire 20-year career with the Yankees before retiring after the 2014 season and was one of the most celebrated, heavily marketed and distinguished players of his era.\n\nHe was a 14-time All-Star, won five Gold Glove Awards, five Silver Slugger awards, two Hank Aaron Awards and is the Yankees' all-time career leader in hits (3,465), doubles (544), games played (2,747), stolen bases (358), times on base (4,716) and at-bats (11,195).\n\nJeter became the 28th player to reach 3,000 hits and finished his career sixth all-time in career hits and the all-time MLB leader in hits by a shortstop.\n\nHe consistently ranked among the American League leaders in hits and runs scored for most of his career, and served as the Yankees' team captain from 2003 until his retirement in 2014.\n\nJeter won five World Series (1996, 1998 through 2000 and 2009) and holds many postseason records.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:15:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"uri": "bostonherald.com", "title": "Boston Herald", "id": "2238"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:15:00", "url": "http://www.bostonherald.com/news/national/2017/08/loria_agrees_to_sell_marlins_to_sherman_and_jeter_source_says", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8702681", "image": "http://www.bostonherald.com/sites/default/files/styles/full/public/media/ap/2017/05/14/bc7e9b41806740668a0ca1a8d3df364d.jpg?itok=TT_2364R", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "21:15:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"body": "It appears the Miami Marlins will soon have a new ownership in place. According to a report from The Miami Herald, Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the team to the group that includes Derek Jeter and New York businessman Bruce Sherman for a cool $1.2 billion.\n\nThe group including Jeter was long expected to be a favorite to land the ownership of the Marlins, although concerns about potentially not having as much to offer for the team was thought to hold back the Jeter group from winning the bidding war. A healthy relationship and respect Loria has for Jeter made the Jeter group one of the top contenders from the start. Jeter reportedly is expected to be putting up $25 million for his ownership stake, which makes him a mere part owner of the team, but it would be wise for the Marlins to put his face in front of as many fans as possible to build a connection with them.\n\nOne other serious bidder, Miami businessman Jorge Mas, made a serious push to buy the team but was unwilling or unable to match the $1.2 billion bid put up by Sherman and Jeter's group. The bidding group that included former Florida Governor Jeb Bush backed out of the bidding process this week.\n\nThe sale of the team, of course, has not been finalized, and there are a few more steps in the process before we can formally recognize \"The Captain\" of the New York Yankees as an official owner in baseball circles. Aside from the legalities of the sale having to be ironed out, Major League Baseball must also approve the sale to the Sherman/Jeter group. But you would think Major League Baseball would never say no to Jeter, so as long as all of the paperwork can be sorted out between Loria and the winning bidders, this sale will easily be approved by the rest of Major League Baseball's owners.\n\nInterestingly enough, the Jeter group consists of 16 bidders. Among them is Michael Jordan. headed by businessman Bruce Sherman and New York Yankees legend Derek Jeter.\n\nA written agreement for $1.2 billion is expected to reach Major League Baseball on Friday, the source said.\n\nThere are 16 investors in Jeter and Sherman's group, the report said.\n\nSherman, a Marlins fan, is known for his philanthropic work and previously was the chairman and chief investment officer of Naples-based Private Capital Management. The two reportedly have a great relationship. Jeter is contributing $25 million himself, the Herald reported.\n\nJeter, a former New York Yankees star and Tampa resident, will run the business and baseball side of the organization, the Herald report, while Sherman will act as the team's managing general partner. Major League Baseball owners must still vote to approve the sale.\n\nSeveral big names were involved, at one time, in the bidding, including Tagg Romney, the son of former presidential candidate Mitt Romney, as well as former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush. Loria bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry.\n\nMarlins president David Samson on Friday declined to comment about where the sales process stood.\n\nJeter, 43, has long talked of his desire to own a team.\n\nA source close to the situation has informed FanRag Sports that progress is now being made toward Derek Jeter's acquisition of the Marlins. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets", "score": 2, "id": "348521", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sun-Sentinel"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun-Sentinel", "score": 3, "id": "358851", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ulcerative colitis"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ulcerative_colitis", "score": 3, "id": "370508", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Samson_(baseball)", "score": 2, "id": "828953", "type": "person"}], "body": "The Miami Marlins sale saga has its next chapter, and maybe a conclusion.\n\nOwner Jeffrey Loria agreed Friday to sell the team for $1.2 billion to a group that's headed by Bruce Sherman -- a retired money manager and longtime Naples resident -- and highlighted by New York Yankees legend Derek Jeter, according to multiple reports.\n\nThe deal is not final yet, and likely won't be for months. It will need approval from 21 of the other 29 major league team owners.\n\nThe Marlins and Major League Baseball, through spokespeople, declined to comment.\n\nJorge Mas, the other primary bidder for the team, has not been officially notified of Loria's agreement with the Sherman/Jeter group, a source close to Mas told the Sun Sentinel on Friday evening. The source said Mas met with MLB officials on Thursday and laid out his group's financing, including investors. Mas was not willing to offer as much as $1.2 billion, according to the source.\n\nA purchase agreement between Loria and the Sherman/Jeter group was expected to be submitted to MLB on Friday, according to the Miami Herald. Fox Business reported that Loria and Sherman/Jeter have a \"handshake deal.\" In April, Loria reached an agreement in principle to sell the team to a group including Jeter and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, but that deal was not completed.\n\nSherman, 69, will be the new ownership group's control person, while Jeter, 43, will run the business and baseball operations departments, the Herald reported. Jeter is said to be investing only $25 million of his own money.\n\nSherman previously headed the Naples-based Private Capital Management. He retired in 2009.\n\nIn recent years, Sherman and his wife, Cynthia, have engaged in philanthropic endeavors through The Bruce & Cynthia Sherman Charitable Foundation. That includes the annual Sherman Prize, a pair of $100,000 awards that honor achievements of those leading the fight against Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Sherman's late father had Crohn's, as do two daughters.\n\nThe Shermans also organize the annual Naples Winter Wine Festival, which has raised more than $161 million for the Naples Children & Education Foundation since 2001.\n\nJeter, who lives in Tampa, has long expressed a desire to own a major league team, but that his group is so close to winning is something of an underdog story. He has been involved with the bidding since the process began, but his ever-shifting group of investors has been hit by key defections, including that of Chicago billionaire Richard Chaifetz last month and Bush in late May.\n\nJeter's current group is comprised of 16 investors, including NBA legend and Charlotte Hornets owner Michael Jordan, according to the Herald. Jordan and Jeter have long been friends.\n\nJeter won five World Series championships in his 20 years playing shortstop for the Yankees. He was briefly teammates with and then coached by current Marlins manager Don Mattingly.\n\nOn Friday at Marlins Park, Mattingly spoke glowingly but in generalities about Jeter, saying he was unaware of any sale deal.\n\n\"Derek has been successful in everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said. \"Good people with the kind of ability that he had as a player, that translates into business just like it does just like it does to anything else. I think that foundation, hard work, determination, confidence, all those things lead you to believe that Derek is going to be successful at whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nThis appears to bring closer to an end a soap opera that has dragged on from the early days of spring training, when club president David Samson said the team was officially for sale. The process continued through the spring, when multiple other groups were reportedly closing in on buying the team, and past baseball's All-Star Game in Miami last month, when Mas seemed to emerge as a late favorite.\n\nA third bidding group, led by Quogue Capital founder Wayne Rothbaum and Bush, had been quieter over the past month-plus and reportedly dropped out of the running completely this week.\n\nBut all along, Loria -- a New York native known to fancy Yankees stars, including Mattingly -- seemed to favor Jeter, allowing him months to recruit the needed financial support.\n\nLoria, who previously owned the Montreal Expos, bought the Marlins for $158 million in 2002. The Marlins won the World Series in 2003 but haven't returned to the playoffs since, and they last had a winning season in 2009.\n\nStaff writers Dave Hyde and Craig Davis contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T23:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"uri": "baltimoresun.com", "title": "The Baltimore Sun", "id": "597"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:28:00", "url": "http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/mlb/fl-reg-loria-agrees-to-sell-marlines-20170811-story.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8718876", "image": "http://www.trbimg.com/img-598e3b4d/turbine/fl-reg-loria-agrees-to-sell-marlines-20170811", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "23:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets", "score": 2, "id": "348521", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sun-Sentinel"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun-Sentinel", "score": 3, "id": "358851", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ulcerative colitis"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ulcerative_colitis", "score": 3, "id": "370508", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Samson_(baseball)", "score": 2, "id": "828953", "type": "person"}], "body": "The Miami Marlins sale saga has its next chapter, and maybe a conclusion.\n\nOwner Jeffrey Loria agreed Friday to sell the team for $1.2 billion to a group that's headed by Bruce Sherman -- a retired money manager and longtime Naples resident -- and highlighted by New York Yankees legend Derek Jeter, according to multiple reports.\n\nThe deal is not final yet, and likely won't be for months. It will need approval from 21 of the other 29 major league team owners.\n\nThe Marlins and Major League Baseball, through spokesmen, declined to comment.\n\nJorge Mas, the other primary bidder for the team, has not been officially notified of Loria's agreement with the Sherman/Jeter group, a source close to Mas told the Sun Sentinel on Friday evening. The source said Mas met with MLB officials on Thursday and laid out his group's financing, including investors. Mas was not willing to offer as much as $1.2 billion, according to the source.\n\nA purchase agreement between Loria and the Sherman/Jeter group was expected to be submitted to MLB on Friday, according to the Miami Herald. Fox Business reported that Loria and Sherman/Jeter have a \"handshake deal.\" In April, Loria reached an agreement in principle to sell the team to a group including Jeter and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, but that deal was not completed.\n\nSherman, 69, will be the new ownership group's control person, while Jeter, 43, will run the business and baseball operations departments, the Herald reported. Jeter is said to be investing only $25 million of his own money.\n\nSherman previously headed the Naples-based Private Capital Management. He retired in 2009.\n\nIn recent years, Sherman and his wife, Cynthia, have engaged in philanthropic endeavors through The Bruce & Cynthia Sherman Charitable Foundation. That includes the annual Sherman Prize, a pair of $100,000 awards that honor achievements of those leading the fight against Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Sherman's late father had Crohn's, as do two daughters.\n\nThe Shermans also organize the annual Naples Winter Wine Festival, which has raised more than $161 million for the Naples Children & Education Foundation since 2001.\n\nJeter, who lives in Tampa, has long expressed a desire to own a major league team, but that his group is so close to winning is something of an underdog story. He has been involved with the bidding since the process began, but his ever-shifting group of investors has been hit by key defections, including that of Chicago billionaire Richard Chaifetz last month and Bush in late May.\n\nJeter's current group is comprised of 16 investors, including NBA legend and Charlotte Hornets owner Michael Jordan, according to the Herald. Jordan and Jeter have long been friends.\n\nJeter won five World Series championships in his 20 years playing shortstop for the Yankees. He was briefly teammates with and then coached by current Marlins manager Don Mattingly.\n\nOn Friday at Marlins Park, Mattingly spoke glowingly but in generalities about Jeter, saying he was unaware of any sale deal.\n\n\"Derek has been successful in everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said. \"Good people with the kind of ability that he had as a player, that translates into business just like it does to anything else. I think that foundation, hard work, determination, confidence, all those things lead you to believe that Derek is going to be successful at whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nMLB's owners are scheduled to meet in Chicago next week, but USA Today and The Herald report that they are not likely to vote on the potential Marlins sale at those meetings.\n\nStill, the agreement appears to bring closer to an end a soap opera that has dragged on from the early days of spring training, when club president David Samson said the team was officially for sale. The process continued through the spring, when multiple other groups were reportedly closing in on buying the Marlins, and past baseball's All-Star Game in Miami last month, when Mas seemed to emerge as a late favorite.\n\nA third bidding group, led by Quogue Capital founder Wayne Rothbaum and Bush, had been quieter over the past month-plus and reportedly dropped out of the running completely this week.\n\nAll along, Loria -- a New York native known to fancy Yankees stars, including Mattingly -- seemed to favor Jeter, allowing him months to recruit the needed financial support.\n\nLoria, who previously owned the Montreal Expos, bought the Marlins for $158 million in 2002. The Marlins won the World Series in 2003 but haven't returned to the playoffs since, and they last had a winning season in 2009.\n\nStaff writers Dave Hyde and Craig Davis contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T23:02:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"uri": "sun-sentinel.com", "title": "SunSentinel", "id": "726"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:02:00", "url": "http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/miami-marlins/fl-reg-loria-agrees-to-sell-marlines-20170811-story.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8852471", "image": "http://www.trbimg.com/img-598e5135/turbine/fl-reg-loria-agrees-to-sell-marlines-20170811", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "23:02:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

endeavor, enhancing the Jeter group's chances to ultimately get the team, sources tell FanRag Sports.\n\nWhile some suggest Jeter is getting closer to winning the team, Miami businessman Jorge Mas is said to remain in the running in a two-group race that finally appears to be heading toward a conclusion.\n\nSherman, the former chairman of Private Capital Management, was originally in for $200 million-plus, making him by far the biggest investor in the Jeter group, but is said by sources to have increased his financial involvement - though some suggest both groups are still working to raise extra cash for the team that is expected to go for close to the $1.2 billion asking price.\n\nEven if Jeter is currently in front, as some are suggesting, this has been a hard one to predict, with many twists and turns along the way.\n\nSince most of Jeter's investment are of the smaller variety -- $5 million to $25 million, including Jeter himself, who's said to be putting in $25 million -- Sherman is coming up big. Sherman, who retired from finance, is a Florida resident.\n\nOne potential hurdle, among a few for Jeter, is that he seeks to be the control person, and other owners have suggested that his expected $25 million investment does not qualify him as a control person; of course, Jeter carries cache for his playing record and image, and they could potentially get around that by listing Sherman as the control person, and giving Jeter significant power though technically not control.\n\nAnother issue could be a side deal for the Jeter group with Michael Dell, which is suspected to be tantamount to a loan at a high (14 percent) rate of interest. That wouldn't likely fly with MLB.\n\nMas is a billionaire, but since MLB requires 40 percent financing, and the team is losing money (it's expected to be close to $70 million in the red this year), like Jeter he has been seeking extra investors.\n\nWhile Mas, a well-respected Miami businessman, would be cheered in the community if he were to get the team, Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria and president David Samson are said to much prefer Jeter as the owner, which is one reason the Wayne Rothbaum-Jeb Bush group recently dropped out, as FanRag Sports first reported.\n\nSamson declined comment on where the negotiations currently stand.\n\nRelated Items:FRS News, Miami Marlins, Todays MLB News", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T14:52:00Z", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "source": {"uri": "fanragsports.com", "title": "FanRag Sports", "id": "16930"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:12:00", "url": "https://www.fanragsports.com/news/heyman-jeter-gets-boost-two-group-derby-buy-marlins/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8717126", "image": "https://d3d2maoophos6y.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/29013540/AP_17135006385682.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "14:52:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

actually owning the Marlins. That was anti-climactic.\n\nThe almost-official sale was reported by the Miami Herald on Friday, as the owner of nearly 16 years, Jeffrey Loria, agreed to give the team to a 16-investor ownership group (fronted by Jeter and NY businessman/venture capitalist Bruce Sherman) for the price of $1.2 billion. A \"New York City-based MLB source\" added that the paperwork is expected to be sent to MLB later in the day on Friday.\n\nSherman is said to be the \"control person,\" meaning he'll basically be a managing partner, while Jeter will helm the business and baseball sides of the franchise.\n\nWhile Jeter is the headliner, he is reportedly only contributing $25 million of Loria's asking price, but apparently has a good enough relationship with Sherman to be granted his new position (it's about who you know, people).\n\nThe sale still needs to be voted on by current owners before it can be official. It is expected to be talked about by them, but not voted on, at the owners meetings next week in Chicago. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Samson_(baseball)", "score": 2, "id": "828953", "type": "person"}], "body": "The Derek Jeter group is working to finalize the deal for about $1.2 billion to buy the Miami Marlins, and the paperwork is being drawn up and could be completed as early as Friday night -- though even an agreement won't quite cement a transition in this drama that's turned into a long-running soap opera.\n\nJeter has been the preferred candidate of Marlins ownership from the beginning, but two things turned the tide in his favor at the end: 1) His partner Bruce Sherman upped his contribution from about $300 million to about $400 million, and 2) Jeter finally relented on the issue of control, understanding in the end that someone such as himself who's putting in $25 million can't be the control person.\n\nBut of course, even if there are signatures soon, there may be a few chapters to go.\n\nThere is word that while Sherman is willing to up his bid, the group is still seeking investors possibly so he could reduce his outlay and/or firm up their finances. The big question all along has not been whether Jeter and Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria, who has preferred Jeter by all accounts, could agree; it is whether the Jeter group's financing is solid.\n\nThere is also the matter of whether Sherman ultimately wants control.\n\nIt's possible Sherman could become the listed control person with Jeter taking an even more active role than his expected title of CEO would suggest. Or Sherman could find someone else to be the control guy. There are said to be about five or six main investors on their team, though Sherman could try to find someone else to take the lead role, if he so chooses.\n\nIt isn't known if he might consider recruiting Jorge Mas, the well-respected Miami businessman, who looks to be the second-place finisher in this derby.\n\nThe Miami Herald first reported there was agreement.\n\nWord is that Jeter has long been the favorite of not only Loria but also team president David Samson. While Samson has said that his own job was not to be part of the negotiations, Jeter has made known that he's willing to keep Samson on in a role. There is said to be a little over a year left on Samson's contract.\n\nBaseball president and general manager Michael Hill is expected to be asked to stay on, though other groups would have likely kept him, too.\n\nOne thing someone connected to the Jeter group has suggested will likely go: the home run sculpture in left-centerfield that was designed by the artist Red Grooms and has been the subject of controversy.\n\nIt should also be noted that, because of the timing of the agreement, there will not be enough time for the other 29 MLB owners to approve any deal at next week's owners meeting, though that hurdle does eventually need to be cleared.\n\nRelated Items:FRS News, Miami Marlins, NL East, Todays MLB News FanRag Sports Daily MLB Newsletter", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T00:04:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"uri": "fanragsports.com", "title": "FanRag Sports", "id": "16930"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:20:00", "url": "https://www.fanragsports.com/mlb/marlins/heyman-jeter-group-finalizing-deal-purchase-marlins/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8742279", "image": "https://d3d2maoophos6y.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/21133152/95316052924_Braves-Marlins.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "00:04:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

short of the initial asking price of $1.3 billion that Loria had hoped to get in the sale. headed by former New York Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter for $1.2 billion, multiple outlets reported on Friday.\n\nThe club has not confirmed the reports, although ESPN -- citing an undisclosed source -- said the deal is likely to be announced \"in the coming days.\"\n\nFinancier Bruce Sherman will hold the controlling interest and plans for Jeter to be the team's chief executive officer, the Miami Herald reported. Jeter reportedly is investing approximately $25 million of his own money.\n\nThe $1.2 billion price tag of the sale is the second-highest in a history for a Major League Baseball team, behind only the Los Angeles Dodgers' $2 billion sale in 2012.\n\nEarlier this year, Jeter was partnering with Jeb Bush in his bid to buy the Marlins, but the former Florida governor dropped out in late May, according to multiple media reports.\n\nLoria purchased the team in 2002 for $158 million, and a year later, the then-Florida Marlins won their second World Series. "548097", "type": "person"}], "body": "Derek Jeter will soon return to Major League Baseball like a boss.\n\nMiami Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the team to a group of investors, which include the former New York Yankees shortstop, The Miami Herald's Barry Jackson reported Friday, citing a MLB source. The group finalized a $1.2 billion purchase agreement with Loria on Friday and submitted it to the MLB office.\n\nVenture capitalist Bruce Sherman is the group's main investor and he'll play a similar role to a managing partner, according to Jackson. But Jeter likely will be the face of the franchise and will run the baseball and business operations. NBA legend Michael Jordan also is among the 16 investors in the group.\n\nThe sale requires the approval of at least 23 of the 30 MLB owners. They'll discuss the Marlins next week in Chicago at a meeting but aren't likely to vote on the matter for another few weeks. They're expected to ratify the sale some time in October.\n\nLoria announced in March his intention to sell the team. Several groups were interested, but the Jeter-Sherman team beat out two other rivals in the final weeks of negotiations.\n\nJeter, 43, will use just $25 million of his own money to buy a stake in the Marlins. "310097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "World Series"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Series", "score": 3, "id": "310292", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Center fielder"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_fielder", "score": 3, "id": "310659", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Closer (baseball)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closer_(baseball)", "score": 2, "id": "310664", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Miami Marlins"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Marlins", "score": 4, "id": "310673", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "At bat"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/At_bat", "score": 2, "id": "311917", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Michael Jordan"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Jordan", "score": 3, "id": "312575", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "New York Yankees"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Yankees", "score": 4, "id": "312732", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Brad Ziegler"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Ziegler", "score": 2, "id": "314217", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Frank McCourt"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_McCourt", "score": 2, "id": "346642", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Christian Yelich"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Marlins_minor_league_players#Christian_Yelich", "score": 3, "id": "348086", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Charlotte Hornets"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets", "score": 2, "id": "348521", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sun-Sentinel"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun-Sentinel", "score": 3, "id": "358851", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "A. J. Ellis"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A._J._Ellis", "score": 3, "id": "425711", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of African-American firsts"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_African-American_firsts", "score": 2, "id": "1366357", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "As the Miami Marlins took the first important step toward the Derek Jeter Era, the name and reputation was enough to generate hope.\n\nThe former New York Yankees captain has yet to speak publicly about plans he and partner Bruce Sherman have if their agreement to purchase the Marlins is approved by major league owners.\n\nFor the moment, word that a deal has been reached for the five-time World Series champion to run the team's baseball and business operations was enough to send a buzz through the clubhouse and fan base.\n\n\"With Derek, his name is synonymous with winning,\" Marlins backup catcher A.J. Ellis said. \"That really is the only thing you need to know, that his commitment and desire to win and everything he did as a player was directed to winning that game and leading his team toward a championship. You can only anticipate that will be his daily expectation here.\"\n\nMarlins president David Samson confirmed Saturday that an agreement was signed about 11:30 p.m. Friday and submitted to Major League Baseball for a group headed by Jeter and Sherman, a retired money manager to purchase the team from Jeffrey Loria.\n\nThe transaction will be reviewed by the ownership committee next week in Chicago, with a target of being voted on in September and a closing by early October. It will require approval from 21 of the other 29 owners.\n\nAccording to numerous reports, the sale price was $1.2 billion. The Jeter-Sherman group outbid two other groups, including one headed by Miami businessman Jorge Mas.\n\n\"The only thing I'll add right now is we feel really good,\" Samson said. \"It was made because we thought it was in the best interest of the franchise to go forward at this time with this group.\n\n\"Bruce Sherman truly is a man who has a passion for baseball and a love of baseball. Derek Jeter is an incredibly capable individual. Forget what he did on the field, he's incredibly capable off the field,\" Samson continued. \"Thinking about what it would mean for our community and our fans, it just made the most sense.\"\n\nSamson said Mas has not joined with Jeter's group, contrary to media reports, and will not be a partner in the agreement that owners will consider in the coming weeks.\n\nA source close to Mas told the Sun Sentinel that Mas has been talking to Sherman and there is a \"better than not chance\" of him joining the group.\n\nMarlins players had not yet been told of the agreement, but there was eagerness in the clubhouse for the matter to be concluded.\n\n\"If that's the case, it's exciting,\" center fielder Christian Yelich said. \"[Jeter] was my favorite player growing up. So to be playing in the organization that he is a potential owner of is exciting.\n\n\"As a player you want to know the direction that you're headed as an organization. I feel like we've kind of been at a standstill this year. To know which way it's going to be will be nice to know. A lot of stuff hasn't been able to happen or can't happen until the new ownership [is in place].\"\n\nSamson confirmed that Sherman, 69, will be the new ownership group's control person, while Jeter, 43, will become the first African-American to head operations of a team in MLB. The former shortstop is believed to be investing $25 million of his own money.\n\nSherman, a Naples resident, headed the Naples-based Private Capital Management before retiring in 2009.\n\nJeter, who lives in Tampa, has expressed an interest in owning a major league team since retiring as a player in 2014. He has been involved throughout the bidding process for the Marlins, beginning early this year, but with an ever-changing group of investors.\n\nJeter's current group is comprised of 16 investors, including NBA legend and Charlotte Hornets owner Michael Jordan.\n\n\"I'm a little more pumped that Michael Jordan's in the group than Jeter,\" quipped closer Brad Ziegler, who allowed one hit in five at-bats to Jeter.\n\nEllis was with the Los Angeles Dodgers through the protracted sage of then-owner Frank McCourt's divorce that led to bankruptcy and ultimately sale of the team to the Guggenheim Group in 2012.\n\nDue to his experience in LA, Ellis said some Marlins teammates have sought his counsel about what to expect as the saga of a potential sale that began in spring training dragged on.\n\n\"Usually when these transactions happen it's very positive because the new ownership will come in and inject new energy and new life and new resources and try to make this the best place it can be,\" Ellis said.\n\nThat has certainly been the case for the Dodgers, who have won several division titles under new ownership and have the best record in baseball this season. They also have the backing of resources in the nation's second-largest market that are not present in Miami, notably a lucrative regional TV deal.\n\nAt this point, what type of leadership and direction Jeter and Sherman will take the Marlins is unknown.\n\n\"When you have someone as decorated as Derek is as player, you just know that same passion and energy is going to transition to his new role,\" Ellis said. \"You can tell he's very meticulous in his decision-making. He's identified that this is a place that can become a winner very quickly, which is very encouraging for all the guys in this clubhouse to know.\"\n\nThe Marlins haven't reached the playoffs since 2003, when they won their second World Series, and haven't had a winning season since 2009.\n\nAmong many questions to be answered is Samson's future with the team. He said that hasn't been determined but that he is open to working with the new owners, saying, \" I have never discussed my status. It's not about me.\"\n\nLoria has not addressed his future plans. He was cited earlier this year as a candidate to become the U.S. ambassador to France. He was an unpopular figure during his 18 years running the Marlins, but Samson said Loria will leave behind a positive legacy.\n\n\"As far as I'm concerned, the stadium that Jeffrey got built is what guaranteed the future of the Marlins,\" Samson said. \"Having this beautiful ballpark. But sometimes, teams change hands. Having Derek Jeter run this team, along with Bruce Sherman, I think it's just an opportunity for a change.\"\n\nWhat form will Jeter's leadership take? Even the players can only guess.\n\n\"I don't know how much we'll actually see him,\" Ziegler said. \"It will be a cool signature to have on a check. Other than that we'll just see how it goes.\"\n\nStaff writer Dave Hyde contributed to this report.\n\ncldavis@sun-sentinel.com; Twitter @CraigDavisRuns; here on Facebook", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T00:11:00Z", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "source": {"uri": "orlandosentinel.com", "title": "Orlando Sentinel", "id": "883"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:11:00", "url": "http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/baseball/fl-sp-marlins-notes-sat-20170812-story.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8856915", "image": "http://www.trbimg.com/img-598f9918/turbine/fl-sp-marlins-notes-sat-20170812", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "00:11:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}
