"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_on_CBS", "score": 2, "id": "485923", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Carlos A. Gim\u00e9nez"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_A._Gim\u00e9nez", "score": 3, "id": "497661", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Governors of Florida"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Florida", "score": 2, "id": "1366586", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Mas to pay at least $200 million to get controlling stake Jeter and partners bought Miami Marlins for $1.2 billion\n\nJorge Mas, who was bidding against Derek Jeter to buy the Miami Marlins, is in talks to join the former Yankees captain's winning bid group as controlling owner of the Major League Baseball team, according to people familiar with the matter.\n\nMas would put in at least $200 million and replace Bruce Sherman as the controlling owner in Jeter's $1.2 billion bid, the people said, asking not to be named because the talks are confidential. Sherman had agreed to put up $400 million to secure approval from MLB officials.\n\nThe former New York Yankees captain and his partners won the Major League Baseball team with a bid of $1.2 billion, a deal that was first reported by the Miami Herald. The offer was chosen by Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria over a lower bid from Mas.\n\nGetting Mas, a Cuban-American entrepreneur, would be a win for MLB, adding an owner with not only deep pockets but strong local roots. The deal requires approval from MLB owners.\n\nRepresentatives for Jeter and Loria didn't immediately respond to requests for comment. A representative for Mas declined to comment.\n\nThe sale ends Loria's controversial reign in South Florida. Loria bought the team in 2002 for $158 million, and the next year, the Marlins won the World Series. They haven't made the playoffs since, and Loria alienated fans by threatening to move the team to secure public funding for Marlins Park and selling off players to minimize the cost of the team's losses. In 2012, a Miami Herald poll put his favorability rating at 6 percent.\n\n\"The people of Miami are happy to have a new ownership group,\" said Carlos Gimenez, mayor of Miami-Dade County. \"I hope there are no holdovers. It would be a mistake for him to start that way,\" he said, referring to Jeter.\n\nSherman, a co-founder and former chairman of Legg Mason Inc.'s Private Capital Management, was poised to become the team's managing partner, according to the earlier Herald report. Jeter, who is contributing $25 million, will run the business and baseball sides of the organization. NBA Hall of Famer Michael Jordan is also part of the group.\n\nThey're getting a team that hasn't had a winning record since 2009. The Marlins are currently in last place in the National League East. Despite a relatively new stadium, attendance is consistently among the lowest in baseball -- so far in 2017, the team's average attendance of 20,796 ranks 28th among 30 teams.\n\nThough the team is losing money, the next ownership group will reap the benefits of a new naming rights deal for the stadium. Team executives have also said they're exploring a reworked local television contract. The current deal with Fox expires after the 2020 season. According to the Miami Herald, the team gets about $20 million a year from Fox, the lowest in baseball.\n\nThis is the second time a Jeter-led bid has won an auction for the Miami franchise. The sale process began in February when Loria came close to a deal with the Kushner family, relatives by marriage to President Donald Trump. In April, Jeter and former Florida Governor Jeb Bush submitted a $1.3 billion offer that was accepted by Loria, though the group was unable to raise enough money to complete the transaction.\n\nAs Jeter pursued a new bid group, other prospective bidders, including Bush, Quogue Capital founder Wayne Rothbaum and Mitt Romney's son, Tagg, pursued their own groups, occasionally teaming up on potential bids. In the end, the Jeter and Mas groups were the only ones left.\n\nAll team sales are subject to approval by MLB. As a 14-time All Star and career Yankee, Jeter isn't expected to have trouble getting the blessing of the league. He's sixth on baseball's all-time hits list (3,465) and a shoo-in to join the Hall of Fame when he's eligible in 2020.\n\nSince retiring, Jeter, 43, has helped launch a handful of business ventures, including The Players Tribune, a publication that features first-person stories by athletes. A Florida resident, he's often spoken about his desire to own an MLB franchise.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T09:05:00Z", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "source": {"uri": "bloomberg.com", "title": "Bloomberg Business", "id": "1749"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:05:00", "url": "https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-12/jorge-mas-is-said-to-be-in-talks-to-join-jeter-for-miami-marlins", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8768881", "image": "https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iupvCzd8P_uM/v0/1200x797.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "09:05:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Skipx\n\nEmbed\n\nx\n\nShare\n\nCLOSE\n\nA group headlined by Derek Jeter is nearing a deal to buy the Miami Marlins for $1.2 billion, according to a report from the New York Post. Time_Sports\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nDerek Jeter is about to become a co-owner of the Miami Marlins. And there is a Naples connection.\n\nMarlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the franchise for $1.2 billion to the New York Yankees legend and his group led by New York businessman and longtime Naples resident Bruce Sherman, a person directly involved with the sale confirmed to USA TODAY.\n\nThe person spoke on condition of anonymity because the sale is not complete.\n\nThe Miami Herald was the first to report the Sherman-Jeter group was in agreement with Loria. Hall of Fame basketball star Michael Jordan is also said to part of the investors.\n\nThe Herald reported that Sherman is a Marlins fan, and the increased his investment in the group after Chicago businessman Richard Chaifetz backed out, and that Jeter is contributing $25 million of his own money but has a strong relationship with Sherman.\n\nMore: Whatever happened to? Naples finance guru Bruce Sherman\n\nMore: Retiring finance guru Bruce Sherman, in rare interview, talks economy, market, Obama\n\nSherman is the former CEO of Naples-based Private Capital Management, a financial advisory firm he sold to Legg Mason in 2001. His wife Cynthia was a partner in Clifford Chance, a large law firm. They've supported many other charitable organizations, including the Naples Children & Education Foundation, which puts on the annual Naples Winter Wine Festival that has raised millions for children in Collier County.\n\nLast year, the Shermans charitable foundation announced the Sherman Prize, which honors those who make exceptional and pioneering contributions in research on Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. The Shermans created the prize to recognize and reward exceptional and pioneering achievements in Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Sherman's two daughters have Crohn's.\n\nAccording to his bio on the Naples Winter Wine Festival website, Sherman engineered the acquisition of several companies, including Local Financial Corporation, a $3 billion bank in Oklahoma which was acquired in 1989 and sold in 1997. Sherman was an accountant in New York with Arthur Young, and left in 1979 to start his career in venture capital, real estate and media assets.\n\nSherman graduated from the University of Rhode Island in 1969 and has a Masters in Business Administration from Bernard Baruch College in 1973.\n\nAs for the Marlins sale, the agreement is expected to be completed on Friday and submitted to Major League Baseball, which likely will not vote on the transaction at next week's owners' meetings in Chicago.\n\nJeter, 43, is expected to run the Marlins' baseball and business side, according to the Herald, with Sherman serving as the club's \"control person\" regarding all matters relating to MLB and the central office.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry. The Marlins won the World Series in 2003 but haven't reached the playoffs since, the longest current drought in the National League.\n\nBefore Friday night's game, Marlins manager Don Mattingly, who also had a storied playing career with the Yankees, told The Associated Press he knew nothing about Jeter becoming a team owner, but predicted he would do well.\n\n\"Derek has been successful at everything he's tried to do,\" Mattingly said. \"What Derek's been able to do with his career, who he is as a person, there's nothing in there that leads you to believe that he's not going to be successful with really whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said it would be good to get Jeter back in the sport.\n\n\"I think Derek Jeter needs to be in the game -- that's the main thing,\" Black said. \"A player like Jeter and what he meant to his generation of players in that era that he played, and now to continue in the game, I think it's wonderful.\"\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T22:40:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"uri": "naplesnews.com", "title": "Naples Daily News", "id": "4337"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:53:00", "url": "http://www.naplesnews.com/story/sports/mlb/2017/08/11/mlb-marlins-reportedly-being-sold-group-including-derek-jeter-naples-bruce-sherman/561452001/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8731508", "image": "https://www.gannett-cdn.com/GDContent/applogos/naplesnews.png", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "22:40:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Jeffrey Loria has reportedly agreed to sell the Marlins to a group headed by businessman Bruce Sherman and New York Yankees legend Derek Jeter.\n\nLoria has agreed to a $1.2 billion sale price for the Marlins. Sherman, a New York-based businessman, will be the controlling owner. Sherman is currently building a home in South Florida, so he will have a connection to the area.\n\nWhile Sherman is the money, Jeter will be in charge of the baseball side of things. Jeter is reportedly investing about $25 million of his own money in the venture.\n\nThe group purchasing the team has roughly 16 investors, including Michael Jordan. A purchase agreement for the team is reportedly expected to be finalized Friday and submitted to Major League Baseball.\n\nSherman is a Marlins fan, and has wanted to buy the team for a while. He increased his investment in the bid after Chicago businessman Richard Chaifetz backed out.\n\nMLB owners and officials are expected to discuss the sale at next week's owners meetings in Chicago. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}], "body": "Retired New York Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter might soon be spending a lot more time in Miami. (Winslow Townson/AP)\n\nAfter months of speculation about who would emerge as the new owner of the Miami Marlins, the world may have finally gotten its answer on Friday. According to the Miami Herald, which cites \"a New York based MLB source,\" current owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the Marlins to former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter and his business partner Bruce Sherman, a New York businessman. The investment group is said to have around 14 other investors, including Michael Jordan, the Herald reports.\n\nIf the deal for the team, valued at $1.3 billion goes through, Sherman would become the managing general partner, while Jeter, who reportedly put in $25 million of his own money, would be the main point person for both business and baseball operations, according to the Herald's source.\n\nLater on Friday, Fox Sports MLB reporter Ken Rosenthal also received confirmation that the Jeter-Sherman group had won the bid.\n\nThe Derek Jeter-Bruce Sherman group has won the bidding for the #Marlins, sources confirm to me and @CGasparino. First: @clarkspencer.\n\n-- Ken Rosenthal (@Ken_Rosenthal) August 11, 2017\n\nThe reports of the winning bid come just days after the Associated Press confirmed a group led by former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and Quogue Capital investment fund founder Wayne Rothbaum had halted its bid for the team. Besides the Jeter group, the only other bidder who remained after Bush-Routhbaum dropped out was one led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, according to the AP. It is not known whether he put in a bid.\n\nNo party connected to the reported deal has commented publicly.\n\nIt will likely be weeks before Jeter's group is confirmed as new ownership. MLB officials need to hold a vote to approve the bid, which the Herald reported may not occur until the first week in October.\n\nOnce approved, add this to Derek Jeter's achievements: First African-American to run business and baseball ops of a major-league club.\n\n-- Ken Rosenthal (@Ken_Rosenthal) August 11, 2017\n\nLoria, who purchased the team for just more than $158 million in 2002, put the team on the market earlier this year after a tumultuous tenure.\n\n[Don't be fooled by the positive All-Star Game vibes: The Marlins are in need of rescue]\n\nThe Marlins, who won the World Series in 2003 and got a new $634 million ballpark in 2012 mostly courtesy of the city of Miami and Miami-Dade County, have traditionally lagged behind other teams in attendance. Earlier this year, the Marlins earned the dubious honor of hosting the lowest-attended MLB game (not played behind closed doors) since 1989 when only 1,590 people showed up to watch the team play the Philadelphia Phillies.\n\nSince the team's inception in 1993, it has never finished the season ranked higher than 26th out of 30 MLB teams regarding average attendance. That peak came last year, when an average of 21,405 fans came to each game. This season, the Marlins are ranked 28th in attendance, attracting an average of 20,796 fans per game, according to ESPN.\n\nRead more:\n\nBills get aggressive off the field with a pair of major preseason trades\n\nEzekiel Elliott's reps promise 'a slew' of new evidence to clear player's name after six-game suspension\n\nNeymar cleared to make PSG debut, as Barcelona struggles to sign replacement\n\nSouth African bodybuilder dies in freak accident after back-flip attempt goes awry", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 1218, "textStart": 1203, "freq": 2}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:43:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "title": "Washington Post", "id": "104"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:43:00", "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/08/11/derek-jeter-led-group-reportedly-wins-bid-to-buy-miami-marlins/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8706648", "image": "https://img.washingtonpost.com/rf/image_1484w/2010-2019/Wires/Images/2014-02-07/AP/Yankees_Jeter-037e7.jpg?t=20170517", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "21:43:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets", "score": 2, "id": "348521", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Deadspin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadspin", "score": 2, "id": "361492", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 4, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Current Major Florida"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Florida", "score": 3, "id": "1366586", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The Miami Marlins finally have a new owner as Jeffrey Loria agreed to sell the team for $1.17 billion to an ownership group. This could signify a potential rebirth for one of baseball's more hapless franchises.\n\nThe ownership group is primarily financed by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, who according to Miami Herald, made his money founding a wealth management firm called Private Capital Management based in Naples, Florida. But the most famous member of this group is not Sherman, but Yankees legend Derek Jeter.\n\nJeter has not been shy about his desire to own a baseball team. He attempted to purchase the Marlins earlier this year as part of a different ownership group led by former Florida governor Jeb Bush. While Jeter will only contribute $25 million for the Marlins purchase, Sherman will allow Jeter to run the Marlins both on the business and baseball side.\n\nTo go from the famous Yankees to the struggling Marlins will be a significant challenge for Jeter. After winning the World Series in 2004, the Marlins have won zero playoff series since then and have been in the cellar of the National League most of the time. If that was not problematic enough, the Marlins have ranked bottom in attendance for 11 of the last 12 seasons despite playing in a major American city.\n\nOthers have pointed out that there is a major difference between being good at playing sports and being good at running a sports team, using the example of Michael Jordan and his ownership of the Charlotte Bobcats/Hornets. Can Jeter really compete with the analysts, businessmen, and technocrats who run most MLB teams today?\n\nBut for most Marlins fans, just punting Loria out the door is a victory in and of itself. The Marlins owner acquired a reputation as a cheapskate who was more obsessed with making a profit than fielding a winning baseball team. There is also how Loria managed to get the city of Miami to essentially give him hundreds of millions, according to Deadspin, to build a new baseball stadium in 2012.\n\nFinishing up Details\n\nHowever, it may be too early for Miami fans to celebrate just yet. The owners of the other MLB franchises will have to meet and approve the agreement, which will not take place for at least a month. Furthermore, other ownership groups attempted to purchase the Marlins earlier, only for the agreement to fall through for various reasons.\n\nBut it does appear that the sale is much more likely to happen than it is not. And while the Marlins have struggled and are losing money, Loria was still able to sell them for the second largest amount ever paid for a MLB franchise. The Marlins have a new stadium, are in a potentially valuable market, and there are far more rich individuals who want to buy a sports team than there are available teams.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T20:46:00Z", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "source": {"uri": "inquisitr.com", "title": "The Inquisitr News", "id": "2639"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:46:00", "url": "http://www.inquisitr.com/4428047/miami-marlins-sold-to-derek-jeter-backed-group/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8842096", "image": "http://cdn.inquisitr.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Derek-Jeter-Miami-purchase.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "20:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Samson (baseball)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Samson_(baseball)", "score": 4, "id": "828953", "type": "person"}], "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Miami Marlins president David Samson says a signed $1.2 billion agreement has been submitted to Major League Baseball to sell the franchise to a group that includes former New York Yankees captain Derek Jeter, and the team expects to close on the deal in early October.\n\nThe MLB ownership committee will review the transaction Wednesday at an owners' meeting in Chicago, Samson said Saturday. He anticipates major league owners will approve the deal in September, and closing will take place shortly after the end of the regular season.\n\nJeter plans be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, who will be the controlling owner. Jeter, a 14-time All-Star shortstop, will be in charge of the business and baseball operations, Samson said.\n\n\"I've gotten to know him through this process,\" Samson said. \"He's an incredibly interesting, articulate, smart, contemplative individual. Forget about Hall of Famer, it's not about that, it's about his ability to run a team and his desire to run a team, and it just came through so clearly what he wanted.\"\n\nAt least 75 percent of the major league clubs must approve the sale by Jeffrey Loria, who has owned the team since 2002. A person familiar with the agreement said Friday the Jeter-Sherman group includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Fla.\n\nSamson said he hasn't discussed his own status with Sherman or Jeter, although there have been reports he'll remain with the organization.\n\n\"I have been here since 2002,\" Samson said. \"I love it here. I would love to stay here. ... If Bruce Sherman and Derek Jeter would like me to serve, then it's something I would certainly talk about.\"\n\nLoria's decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest emerged in April. The Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations.\n\n\"It is a process that has had a lot of twists and turns,\" said Samson, speaking in the Marlins' dugout during batting practice before their game against Colorado.\n\n\"We feel really good. It was very important from Jeffrey's standpoint that there was an ownership group that had not just connections to Miami, but an understanding of what it means to be here in Miami and run a team like the Miami Marlins, and all the possibilities that come with being in a great city like ours.\"\n\nMany around baseball predicted success for the new regime.\n\n\"So Jeter's going to run the Marlins, huh? Great choice,\" Baltimore Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. \"Glad they're not in our league.\"\n\nLoria, 76, has long been criticized for his frugal ways and for the public financing that helped build 5-year-old Marlins Park. The Marlins haven't been to the postseason since 2003, and ranked last in the National League in attendance 11 of the past 12 years.\n\nBut Samson defended Loria, who has owned the team -- now in its 25th season -- longer than predecessors Wayne Huizenga or John Henry combined.\n\n\"I think time will show that through thick or thin, his commitment to Miami never wavered,\" Samson said. \"And it was hard to say that about previous owners.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T02:08:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "pjstar.com", "title": "Journal Star", "id": "578"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:08:00", "url": "http://www.pjstar.com/sports/20170812/marlins-confirm-12-billion-deal-to-sell-to-jeter-group?rssfeed=true", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8862780", "image": "http://www.pjstar.com/storyimage/IP/20170812/SPORTS/170819803/AR/0/AR-170819803.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "02:08:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}], "body": "MIAMI -- The Miami Marlins told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter, a person familiar with the negotiations said Friday.\n\nJeter would be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, said the person, who confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the team had not commented publicly.\n\nThe person said MLB was told owner Jeffrey Loria's sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nAmong them is Sherman, who would be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nJeter would be in charge of baseball operations, said the person, who added the Marlins told MLB they intended to sign the sale agreement Friday night.\n\nThe Sherman-Jeter group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations. One group was led by South Florida businessman Jorge Mas, and another included former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who recently halted his pursuit of a deal.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said a month ago that all three groups offered about the same amount of money, but there were legal and financing issues that slowed the process. Jeter had trouble raising money as he sought additional investors.\n\nLoria, 76, bought the Marlins for $158.5 million in 2002 from John Henry, who was part of a group that bought the Boston Red Sox.\n\nMLB owners meet next week in Chicago. A sale requires approval of at least 75 percent of the major league clubs, and the approval process could take three to six months.\n\nMARINERS: In the middle of the AL wild-card race, Seattle will likely be without left-handed ace James Paxton for at least three weeks because of a pectoral strain.\n\nPaxton was put on the 10-day disabled list a day after he was pulled in the seventh inning of his start against the Angels.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? $1.2 billion agreement has been submitted to Major League Baseball to sell the franchise to a group that includes former New York Yankees captain Derek Jeter, and the team expects to close on the deal in early October.\n\nThe MLB ownership committee will review the transaction Wednesday at an owners' meeting in Chicago, Samson said Saturday. He anticipates major league owners will approve the deal in September, and closing will take place shortly after the end of the regular season.\n\nJeter plans be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, who will be the controlling owner. Jeter, a 14-time All-Star shortstop, will be in charge of the business and baseball operations, Samson said.\n\n\"I've gotten to know him through this process,\" Samson said. \"He's an incredibly interesting, articulate, smart, contemplative individual. Forget about Hall of Famer, it's not about that, it's about his ability to run a team and his desire to run a team, and it just came through so clearly what he wanted.\"\n\nAt least 75 percent of the major league clubs must approve the sale by Jeffrey Loria, who has owned the team since 2002. A person familiar with the agreement said Friday the Jeter-Sherman group includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nSamson said he hasn't discussed his own status with Sherman or Jeter, although there have been reports he'll remain with the organization.\n\n\"I have been here since 2002,\" Samson said. \"I love it here. I would love to stay here. ... If Bruce Sherman and Derek Jeter would like me to serve, then it's something I would certainly talk about.\"\n\nLoria's decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest emerged in April. The Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations.\n\n\"It is a process that has had a lot of twists and turns,\" said Samson, speaking in the Marlins' dugout during batting practice before their game against Colorado.\n\n\"We feel really good. It was very important from Jeffrey's standpoint that there was an ownership group that had not just connections to Miami, but an understanding of what it means to be here in Miami and run a team like the Miami Marlins, and all the possibilities that come with being in a great city like ours.\"\n\nMany around baseball predicted success for the new regime.\n\n\"So Jeter's going to run the Marlins, huh? Great choice,\" Baltimore Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. \"Glad they're not in our league.\"\n\nLoria, 76, has long been criticized for his frugal ways and for the public financing that helped build 5-year-old Marlins Park. The Marlins haven't been to the postseason since 2003, and ranked last in the National League in attendance 11 of the past 12 years.\n\nBut Samson defended Loria, who has owned the team -- now in its 25th season -- longer than predecessors Wayne Huizenga or John Henry combined.\n\n\"I think time will show that through thick or thin, his commitment to Miami never wavered,\" Samson said. \"And it was hard to say that about previous owners.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T00:29:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"uri": "dentonrc.com", "title": "dentonrc.com", "id": "2278"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:29:00", "url": "http://www.dentonrc.com/sports/sports-ap-headlines/2017/08/12/marlins-confirm-12-billion-deal-sell-jeter-group", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8857977", "image": "https://dentonrc.imgix.net/1502584025-Rockies-Marlins-Baseball.jpg?w=1200&h=630&format=jpg&crop=faces&fit=crop", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "00:29:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

anonymity Friday because the team had not commented publicly. "Marlins Park"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marlins_Park", "score": 2, "id": "322745", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Dugout (baseball)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dugout_(baseball)", "score": 2, "id": "331803", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Buck Showalter"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buck_Showalter", "score": 2, "id": "358564", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Wayne Huizenga"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayne_Huizenga", "score": 1, "id": "578485", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "David Samson (baseball)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Samson_(baseball)", "score": 4, "id": "828953", "type": "person"}], "body": "MIAMI (AP) - Miami Marlins president David Samson says a signed $1.2 billion agreement has been submitted to Major League Baseball to sell the franchise to a group that includes former New York Yankees captain Derek Jeter, and the team expects to close on the deal in early October.\n\nThe MLB ownership committee will review the transaction Wednesday at an owners' meeting in Chicago, Samson said Saturday. He anticipates major league owners will approve the deal in September, and closing will take place shortly after the end of the regular season.\n\nJeter plans be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, who will be the controlling owner. Jeter, a 14-time All-Star shortstop, will be in charge of the business and baseball operations, Samson said.\n\n\"I've gotten to know him through this process,\" Samson said. \"He's an incredibly interesting, articulate, smart, contemplative individual. Forget about Hall of Famer, it's not about that, it's about his ability to run a team and his desire to run a team, and it just came through so clearly what he wanted.\"\n\nAt least 75 percent of the major league clubs must approve the sale by Jeffrey Loria, who has owned the team since 2002. A person familiar with the agreement said Friday the Jeter-Sherman group includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nSamson said he hasn't discussed his own status with Sherman or Jeter, although there have been reports he'll remain with the organization.\n\n\"I have been here since 2002,\" Samson said. \"I love it here. I would love to stay here. ... If Bruce Sherman and Derek Jeter would like me to serve, then it's something I would certainly talk about.\"\n\nLoria's decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest emerged in April. The Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations.\n\n\"It is a process that has had a lot of twists and turns,\" said Samson, speaking in the Marlins' dugout during batting practice before their game against Colorado.\n\n\"We feel really good. It was very important from Jeffrey's standpoint that there was an ownership group that had not just connections to Miami, but an understanding of what it means to be here in Miami and run a team like the Miami Marlins, and all the possibilities that come with being in a great city like ours.\"\n\nMany around baseball predicted success for the new regime.\n\n\"So Jeter's going to run the Marlins, huh? Great choice,\" Baltimore Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. \"Glad they're not in our league.\"\n\nLoria, 76, has long been criticized for his frugal ways and for the public financing that helped build 5-year-old Marlins Park. The Marlins haven't been to the postseason since 2003, and ranked last in the National League in attendance 11 of the past 12 years.\n\nBut Samson defended Loria, who has owned the team - now in its 25th season - longer than predecessors Wayne Huizenga or John Henry combined.\n\n\"I think time will show that through thick or thin, his commitment to Miami never wavered,\" Samson said. \"And it was hard to say that about previous owners.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writer Janie McCauley in San Francisco contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. "822368", "type": "person"}], "body": "An investment group led by a New York businessman and Players Tribune editor-in-chief Derek Jeter has made the winning bid to buy the Miami Marlins, according to multiple reports.\n\nThe Miami Herald first reported that Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria had agreed to sell the team for $1.2 billion on Friday evening, to a group led by investor Bruce Sherman and the former Yankee shortstop. The deal will still have to approved by three-quarters of baseball's owners.\n\nSherman is going to be the managing general partner of the team, according to the Herald, while Jeter, who put in about $25 million, will focus on the player development and business sides of the team. In addition to Jeter, the ownership group has an athletic dimension thanks to a stake from Michael Jordan, who invested an unknown amount of money with the group.\n\nAccording to the Post, Jeter's interest in being a team executive is fueled by a desire to one day buy a franchise on his own, much like how Jordan was a Washington Wizards executive and then eventually bought the Charlotte Bobcats.\n\nThe Jeter/Sherman group beat out a number of other offers, including one led by a Miami businessman and another led by an investment banker, Tagg Romney and Jeb! Bush. Jeb! and Jeter were originally in on an effort to buy the team together, but that attempt fell apart in a power struggle when Jeb! realized that Jeter wanted to run the business and baseball sides of the franchise.\n\nIf their bid is approved by baseball's owner's, the Jeter/Sherman ownership group will acquire a team with one of baseball's best power hitters, extremely low attendance numbers despite a garish home run sculpture and a stadium whose financing deal will cost the city of Miami billions of dollars in the future.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T14:25:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"uri": "gothamist.com", "title": "Gothamist", "id": "4124"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:25:00", "url": "http://gothamist.com/2017/08/12/derek_jeter-led_investors_group_pur.php", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8803556", "image": "http://gothamist.com/assets_c/2017/08/081217jeter-thumb-640xauto-1008811.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "14:25:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Samson_(baseball)", "score": 4, "id": "828953", "type": "person"}], "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Miami Marlins president David Samson says a signed $1.2 billion agreement has been submitted to Major League Baseball to sell the franchise to a group that includes former New York Yankees captain Derek Jeter, and the team expects to close on the deal in early October.\n\nThe MLB ownership committee will review the transaction Wednesday at an owners' meeting in Chicago, Samson said Saturday. He anticipates major league owners will approve the deal in September, and closing will take place shortly after the end of the regular season.\n\nJeter plans be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, who will be the controlling owner. Jeter, a 14-time All-Star shortstop, will be in charge of the business and baseball operations, Samson said.\n\n\"I've gotten to know him through this process,\" Samson said. \"He's an incredibly interesting, articulate, smart, contemplative individual. Forget about Hall of Famer, it's not about that, it's about his ability to run a team and his desire to run a team, and it just came through so clearly what he wanted.\"\n\nAt least 75 percent of the major league clubs must approve the sale by Jeffrey Loria, who has owned the team since 2002. A person familiar with the agreement said Friday the Jeter-Sherman group includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nSamson said he hasn't discussed his own status with Sherman or Jeter, although there have been reports he'll remain with the organization.\n\n\"I have been here since 2002,\" Samson said. \"I love it here. I would love to stay here. ... If Bruce Sherman and Derek Jeter would like me to serve, then it's something I would certainly talk about.\"\n\nLoria's decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest emerged in April. The Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations.\n\n\"It is a process that has had a lot of twists and turns,\" said Samson, speaking in the Marlins' dugout during batting practice before their game against Colorado.\n\n\"We feel really good. It was very important from Jeffrey's standpoint that there was an ownership group that had not just connections to Miami, but an understanding of what it means to be here in Miami and run a team like the Miami Marlins, and all the possibilities that come with being in a great city like ours.\"\n\nMany around baseball predicted success for the new regime.\n\n\"So Jeter's going to run the Marlins, huh? Great choice,\" Baltimore Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. \"Glad they're not in our league.\"\n\nLoria, 76, has long been criticized for his frugal ways and for the public financing that helped build 5-year-old Marlins Park. The Marlins haven't been to the postseason since 2003, and ranked last in the National League in attendance 11 of the past 12 years.\n\nGet the latest sports news and scores sent to your email inbox Sign Up! I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site consitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.\n\nBut Samson defended Loria, who has owned the team -- now in its 25th season -- longer than predecessors Wayne Huizenga or John Henry combined.\n\n\"I think time will show that through thick or thin, his commitment to Miami never wavered,\" Samson said. \"And it was hard to say that about previous owners.\"\n\n-- -- --\n\nAP Sports Writer Janie McCauley in San Francisco contributed to this report.\n\n-- -- --\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\n-- -- --\n\nFollow Steven Wine on Twitter: http://twitter.com/Steve -- Wine", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T22:27:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"uri": "magicvalley.com", "title": "Twin Falls Times-News", "id": "8898"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:27:00", "url": "http://magicvalley.com/sports/baseball/professional/marlins-confirm-billion-deal-to-sell-to-jeter-group/article_b364ecab-f3e2-5a33-bef6-36c5aae011f0.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8850231", "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/magicvalley.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/8/6a/86ad594a-315c-53d9-9b0d-12ef1bbd7ae7/598e4808a2916.image.jpg?crop=512%2C288%2C0%2C19&resize=512%2C288&order=crop%2Cresize", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "22:27:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Samson_(baseball)", "score": 4, "id": "828953", "type": "person"}], "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Miami Marlins president David Samson says a signed $1.2 billion agreement has been submitted to Major League Baseball to sell the franchise to a group that includes former New York Yankees captain Derek Jeter, and the team expects to close on the deal in early October.\n\nThe MLB ownership committee will review the transaction Wednesday at an owners' meeting in Chicago, Samson said Saturday. He anticipates major league owners will approve the deal in September, and closing will take place shortly after the end of the regular season.\n\nJeter plans be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, who will be the controlling owner. Jeter, a 14-time All-Star shortstop, will be in charge of the business and baseball operations, Samson said.\n\n\"I've gotten to know him through this process,\" Samson said. \"He's an incredibly interesting, articulate, smart, contemplative individual. Forget about Hall of Famer, it's not about that, it's about his ability to run a team and his desire to run a team, and it just came through so clearly what he wanted.\"\n\nAt least 75 percent of the major league clubs must approve the sale by Jeffrey Loria, who has owned the team since 2002. A person familiar with the agreement said Friday the Jeter-Sherman group includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nSamson said he hasn't discussed his own status with Sherman or Jeter, although there have been reports he'll remain with the organization.\n\n\"I have been here since 2002,\" Samson said. \"I love it here. I would love to stay here. ... If Bruce Sherman and Derek Jeter would like me to serve, then it's something I would certainly talk about.\"\n\nLoria's decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest emerged in April. The Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations.\n\n\"It is a process that has had a lot of twists and turns,\" said Samson, speaking in the Marlins' dugout during batting practice before their game against Colorado.\n\n\"We feel really good. It was very important from Jeffrey's standpoint that there was an ownership group that had not just connections to Miami, but an understanding of what it means to be here in Miami and run a team like the Miami Marlins, and all the possibilities that come with being in a great city like ours.\"\n\nMany around baseball predicted success for the new regime.\n\n\"So Jeter's going to run the Marlins, huh? Great choice,\" Baltimore Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. \"Glad they're not in our league.\"\n\nLoria, 76, has long been criticized for his frugal ways and for the public financing that helped build 5-year-old Marlins Park. The Marlins haven't been to the postseason since 2003, and ranked last in the National League in attendance 11 of the past 12 years.\n\nBut Samson defended Loria, who has owned the team -- now in its 25th season -- longer than predecessors Wayne Huizenga or John Henry combined.\n\n\"I think time will show that through thick or thin, his commitment to Miami never wavered,\" Samson said. \"And it was hard to say that about previous owners.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writer Janie McCauley in San Francisco contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T22:25:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"uri": "seattlepi.com", "title": "seattlepi.com", "id": "19267"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:25:00", "url": "http://www.seattlepi.com/sports/article/AP-source-Marlins-sign-agreement-to-sell-to-11778979.php", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8850065", "image": "http://ww3.hdnux.com/photos/64/31/02/13734058/3/rawImage.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "22:25:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

to buy the Marlins\n\nThe Miami Marlins have officially recognized a winner bidder for the sale of the team, according to Ken Rosenthal. The Marlins originally agreed to sell the team this past offseason, and up until now they had really struggled to sell the organization. On Friday, the Derek Jeter and Bruce Sherman group won the bidding for $1.2 billion. Sherman will reportedly be the control person while Jeter will be the CEO.\n\nBack in May, previous owner Jeffrey Loria was in a precarious situation. He either had to cut the price a second time or he had to take his team off the market. Obviously, the former was the result, and Jeter and company look to hopefully turn this franchise around from its money-losing ways.\n\nThe Marlins are expected to lose more than $60 million this season due to one of the lowest revenues in baseball, and their $115 million payroll is the largest in franchise history. Add a low-paying TV contract, and an average attendance that's regularly in the bottom five in baseball and it's a financial black hole.\n\nLoria had owned the team since 2002, winning a World Series in 2003, but they haven't made the playoffs since then. Only the Mariners have a longer playoff drought in baseball.\n\nThe selling of the franchise could start to get the ball rolling on making the organization better on the field. If you recall, during the deadline, the Marlins flirted with trading their core three in Christian Yelich, Marcell Ozuna and Giancarlo Stanton, but couldn't in part because the team hadn't been sold yet.\n\nNow at this point, neither of the three players are going to make it through waivers, but this winter they could be shopped -- especially Stanton.\n\nWith Jeter expected to run the baseball side of things, it'll be interesting to see if under new ownership they can not only turn it around financially, but performance wise as well.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"uri": "fansided.com", "title": "FanSided", "id": "8632"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:53:00", "url": "https://fansided.com/2017/08/11/miami-marlins-sale-derek-jeter-group/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8731505", "image": "https://imagesvc.timeincapp.com/v3/fan/image?&url=https://fansided.com/wp-content/uploads/getty-images/2017/08/683312950-techcrunch-disrupt-ny-2017-day-1.jpg.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:17:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Bronx, it appears that Derek Jeter will pursue a sixth World Series ring as the next chief executive officer of the Marlins, now that the team's owner Jeffrey Loria reportedly has accepted the $1.2-billion bid of the group headlined by the former Yankees' captain.\n\nJeter had spent the past few months rounding up investors to meet Loria's asking price, and that finally came together Friday, with New York venture capitalist Bruce Sherman putting up the majority stake, according to multiple reports.\n\nMost popular baseball stories Mets defend not trading Jay Bruce to Yankees Yanks put Clint Frazier on DL, activate Hicks Dominic Smith to join Mets on Friday Jays blank Yankees, who fall 4 1/2 games back Yanks' Bird, Castro making progress in rehab\n\nThe Miami Herald was first with the details of the agreement, which will now have to be voted on by the other 29 owners. The deal needs 75 percent approval, but with the commissioner's office seemingly in Jeter's corner all along, that shouldn't be an issue.\n\nJeter's pursuit of the Marlins has been going on since this baseball season began, and there were indications that he had the inside track as early as May before former Florida Governor Jeb Bush dropped out of his ownership group and later joined another.\n\nThe Yankees were unavailable to comment before Friday's series opener against the Red Sox, but their reaction isn't likely to be much different than in April, when many were asked about the possibility of Jeter being part owner of the Marlins.\n\nDerek Jeter lines up a putt during the Celebrity Foursome to benefit the American Family Children's Hospital held during the second round of the American Family Insurance Championship at University Ridge Golf Course on June 24, 2017 in Madison, Wisconsin. Photo Credit: Getty Images / Michael Cohen\n\n\"He's a guy, no matter what he's involved in, he's going to be successful,\" Brett Gardner, a teammate of Jeter's from 2008-2014, said at the time. \"I'm excited for him.\"\n\nadvertisement | advertise on newsday\n\nJeter reportedly is only one of approximately 16 investors, a collection that also includes former NBA great Michael Jordan, who recently came on board as Jeter still was in the recruiting process. The Miami Herald reported that Sherman will have control over the Marlins, and Jeter -- who is investing roughly $25 million himself -- will handle the baseball and business operations. It's a mammoth undertaking for a rookie CEO like Jeter, and history has shown that these transitions don't necessary guarantee success.\n\n\"Great players don't always translate to great executives, as we've seen,\" CC Sabathia said back in April. \"So we'll have to wait and see what happens for him. Like I said, he's wanted to do this, he's very capable of doing this. We'll have to see how it plays out . . . but I think Jete has a lot to offer. committee will review the transaction Wednesday at an owners' meeting in Chicago, Samson said Saturday. He anticipates major league owners will approve the deal in September, and closing will take place shortly after the end of the regular season.\n\nJeter plans be a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman, who will be the controlling owner. Jeter, a 14-time All-Star shortstop, will be in charge of the business and baseball operations, Samson said.\n\n\"I've gotten to know him through this process,\" Samson said. \"He's an incredibly interesting, articulate, smart, contemplative individual. Forget about Hall of Famer, it's not about that, it's about his ability to run a team and his desire to run a team, and it just came through so clearly what he wanted.\"\n\nAt least 75 percent of the major league clubs must approve the sale by Jeffrey Loria, who has owned the team since 2002. A person familiar with the agreement said Friday the Jeter-Sherman group includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman spent much of his financial career in New York and has a home in Naples, Florida.\n\nSamson said he hasn't discussed his own status with Sherman or Jeter, although there have been reports he'll remain with the organization.\n\n\"I have been here since 2002,\" Samson said. \"I love it here. I would love to stay here. ... If Bruce Sherman and Derek Jeter would like me to serve, then it's something I would certainly talk about.\"\n\nLoria's decision to sell the team became public in February, and Jeter's interest emerged in April. The Jeter-Sherman group beat out two other groups that pursued the team in the final weeks of negotiations.\n\n\"It is a process that has had a lot of twists and turns,\" said Samson, speaking in the Marlins' dugout during batting practice before their game against Colorado.\n\n\"We feel really good. It was very important from Jeffrey's standpoint that there was an ownership group that had not just connections to Miami, but an understanding of what it means to be here in Miami and run a team like the Miami Marlins, and all the possibilities that come with being in a great city like ours.\"\n\nMany around baseball predicted success for the new regime.\n\n\"So Jeter's going to run the Marlins, huh? Great choice,\" Baltimore Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. \"Glad they're not in our league.\"\n\nLoria, 76, has long been criticized for his frugal ways and for the public financing that helped build 5-year-old Marlins Park. The Marlins haven't been to the postseason since 2003, and ranked last in the National League in attendance 11 of the past 12 years.\n\nBut Samson defended Loria, who has owned the team - now in its 25th season - longer than predecessors Wayne Huizenga or John Henry combined.\n\n\"I think time will show that through thick or thin, his commitment to Miami never wavered,\" Samson said. \"And it was hard to say that about previous owners.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writer Janie McCauley in San Francisco contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\n___\n\nFollow Steven Wine on Twitter: http://twitter.com/Steve_Wine", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T13:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"uri": "fox13memphis.com", "title": "WHBQ", "id": "114"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:17:00", "url": "http://www.fox13memphis.com/news/ap-source-marlins-sign-agreement-to-sell-to-jeter-group/589556959", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8919290", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "13:17:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Bruce Sherman.\n\nThe person confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity Friday because the team had not commented publicly. The person said MLB has been told the sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman would be the controlling owner, the person said. Tarasco"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Tarasco", "score": 1, "id": "1181075", "type": "person"}], "body": "1 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nJeffrey Loria, the soon-to-be-former owner of the Miami Marlins, has always loved the New York Yankees.\n\nIt's his favorite team.\n\nHe goes to games at Yankee Stadium.\n\nHe lives in New York.\n\nHe collects art there.\n\nHighest bidder: Jeter-led group agrees to buy Marlins for $1.2 billion\n\nAnd ever since he decided to sell the Marlins, he's always wanted the franchise to go to Derek Jeter.\n\nSo he waited.\n\nThe Jed Bush group came and went. The Mitt Romney group disappeared. New York businessman Wayne Rothbaum bowed out. Miami businessman Jorge Mas jumped in late, but didn't come up with the money.\n\nSo Loria waited, and waited, and finally, with New York businessman Bruce Sherman joining Jeter's group, they came up with the minimum price Loria desired at $1.2 billion.\n\nThe deal was finalized Friday, a high-ranking executive with direct knowledge of the sale confirmed to USA TODAY Sports, but spoke only on the condition of anonymity, since the proposed sale has yet to be presented to Major League Baseball.\n\nSherman will be the control person. Jeter will be the baseball and business man, and everyone in the MLB offices on Park Avenue in N.Y. are ecstatic.\n\nJeter, one of the iconic names in all of baseball, with five World Series rings and a 14-time All-Star, is back in the game and immediately becomes the most famous face in baseball's ownership circles, supplanting minority owner Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Dodgers.\n\nSure, Jeter is only putting in about $25 million of his own cash.\n\nYes, Jeter has zero front office experience.\n\nAnd, yes, the team is in financial disarray, with projected losses of at least $60 million this season while the team already is in about $500 million of debt.\n\nYet, there finally is hope that the Marlins will be a valuable franchise again, knowing that whatever Jeter has touched, whether it's his Yankee teams, his brands, or even his website, has turned to gold.\n\nThe news of the sale will surely dominate the MLB owners' meetings next week in Chicago, but no vote will be taken. Sherman and Jeter still have to meet with the ownership committee, there will be a recommendation, and finally a vote.\n\nThe deal should be finalized in October, far too late to save this season, but in plenty of time to save the franchise.\n\nIt's a happy day in Florida, and throughout the game of baseball.\n\nJeter is back.\n\nAnd, just maybe, so are the Marlins.\n\nFollow Nightengale on Twitter and Facebook\n\nGALLERY: Derek Jeter; Yankees legendDerek Jeter through the years Fullscreen Sept. 25, 2014: Jeter celebrates his walk-off single against the Orioles in his final at-bat at Yankee Stadium. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Samson_(baseball)", "score": 2, "id": "828953", "type": "person"}], "body": "The Derek Jeter group is said by sources to be closing in on a deal to buy the Marlins, sources confirm.\n\nThough there have been many twists and turns in one of the most unpredictable sales in baseball, the Jeter group that is financed strongly now by Bruce Sherman is said by sources to be on the cusp of finalizing the agreement.\n\nThe Miami Herald first reported Friday afternoon that there was an agreement with Jeter. The other leading prospective buyer, Miami businessman Jorge Mas, has not yet been told of any finalized deal, which is believed to be worth $1.2 billion.\n\nSherman, who is putting in the bulk of the money, and as FanRag reported Thursday, recently upped his bid, would be the official control person if the deal goes through. Jeter would have a major role, but MLB people have said that he can't be the control person since he's putting in only about $25 million. Beyond Sherman, most of the other members of Jeter's group are smaller investments, with $5 million, $10 million and $20 million increments. Basketball superstar Michael Jordan is mostly lending his name, and is believed to be contributing no more than a few million dollars, if that.\n\nSources say Jeter's intention is to keep team president David Samson, the stepson of current Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria, in some role, and while Samson has said that wasn't part of the negotiation, others say that differentiated Jeter's group from the others, as it's highly unusual to keep a big person in the outgoing group. Baseball president Michael Hill is expected to stay on in a role as well (other groups intended to keep him as well).\n\nJeter has been the preferred buyer all along, but for a long time he had been well short of the funds. It appears the deal was kept alive long enough for him to garner the funds, asssuming this goes through.\n\nMajor League Baseball owners would still need to approve any potential new owners.\n\nRelated Items:FRS News, Miami Marlins, NL East, Todays MLB News", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:52:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"uri": "fanragsports.com", "title": "FanRag Sports", "id": "16930"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:12:00", "url": "https://www.fanragsports.com/news/heyman-jeter-group-closing-marlins-purchase/", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8717134", "image": "https://www.fanragsports.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/AP_17135054837555.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:52:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Florida"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Florida", "score": 2, "id": "1366586", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Miami Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the team for $1.2 billion to a group led by New York Yankees legend Derek Jeter and New York businessman Bruce Sherman, the Miami Herald reported on Friday. Major League Baseball is expected to receive the written agreement on Friday.\n\nAccording to the Miami Herald report, Jeter is believed to be contributing only $25 million of his own money. Sherman, who will reportedly assume a role similar to a managing general partner, and a group of 16 investors were called on to help bolster the group's bid. The investors are reported to include NBA legends Michael Jordan, whose friendship with Jeter has been well documented.\n\n[Now's the time to sign up for Fantasy Football! Join for free]\n\nThe sale would need approval from the league before becoming official. According to the Miami Herald report, a resolution may not come until October. MLB officials are expected to discuss the sale when owners meet in Chicago next week. A vote then is considered unlikely.\n\nThe Jeter/Sherman group edged out Miami businessman Jorge Mas and his contingent. The Mas group was considered a strong favorite as recently as the All-Star game, which took place in Miami and saw Mas sharing the owner's box with Loria throughout the events.\n\nAs MLB Network's Ken Rosenthal notes, once the deal is approved, Jeter will become the first African-American to run the business and baseball operations for a major-league club.\n\nOddly enough, it was Jeter's desire to control both of those elements that ultimately led to his partnership with former Florida governor Jeb Bush falling apart. Some believed Bush's departure would be a crippling blow to Jeter's bid, but once Bush and new partner Wayne Rothbaum dropped out of the running this week Jeter's group was able to rebuild its momentum and now seems poised to run the show on South Beach.\n\nMore MLB coverage from Yahoo Sports:\n\n- - - - - - -\n\nMark Townsend is a writer for Big League Stew on Yahoo Sports. legend and Kalamazoo native, appears to be set to become a major-league owner.\n\nAccording to a report in the Miami Herald on Friday afternoon, Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria has agreed to sell the franchise to a group led by Jeter and New York businessman Bruce Sherman for $1.2 billion.\n\nMLB was to receive a written agreement later Friday, a source told the Herald.\n\nJeter is expected to contribute $25 million and run the baseball operations, the Herald reported. The Herald reported there are 16 investors.\n\nSeveral big names were involved, at one time, in the bidding, including Tagg Romney, the son of former presidential candidate Mitt Romney, as well as former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush.\n\nJeter, 43, was the No. 6 overall pick in the 1992 draft, out of Kalamazoo Central High School. He debuted for the Yankees in 1995 and played his entire career in pinstripes, retiring at the end of the 2014 season. He won five World Series championship, was the 1996 rookie of the year and was a 14-time All-Star and five-time Gold Glove winner.\n\nHe played 20 years in all, batting .310/.377/.440 with 260 home runs, 1,311 RBIs, 358 stolen bases and 3,465 hits.\n\nSince retiring, he's been involved in a number of business ventures, including with the website The Players' Tribune. He also has attended multiple Michigan football games, and has served as an honorary captain. "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}], "body": "\"Marlins Man\" has been seen at the biggest venues and all the biggest games in baseball over the past five years.\n\nAnd like you, Laurence Leavy is hoping the pending purchase by the group led by Derek Jeter fires up a lackluster Marlins fan base.\n\n\"I'm happy the Marlins are sold because they need a fresh start,\" Leavy said. \"I definitely want to energize the fan base that lacks the energy I see all the time at baseball stadiums across the country.\"\n\nThe Miami Herald reported Friday that longtime owner Jeffrey Loria had reached an agreement to sell the franchise for $1.2 billion to a group led by New York businessman Bruce Sherman and Jeter.\n\nLeavy was in New York Friday and said he will be in New York next week for the Subway Series and later when the Marlins play the Mets at Citi Field where he will watch from his customary front-row seats behind home plate.\n\n\"If it is sold, I'm happy it's Jeter,\" Leavy said. \"Jeter is a good guy and, hopefully, he will bring class to the organization.\n\n\"They say in life that insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting the same result. Well, that's what the Marlins have been the last five years.\"\n\nOn Friday, some of the fans flocking to Marlins Park to watch them take on the Rockies still hadn't heard the news of the pending sale to Jeter's group.\n\nTheir reactions were like a kid on Christmas morning.\n\n\"I'm happy and excited,\" said John Rivera, who has been a Marlins' fan since 2005. \"I think [Jeffrey Loria] just bought the team for business purposes and cared only about his wealth. I think the Marlins as a whole organization need a fresh start.\"\n\nJason Reinhard, a native of Allentown, Pennsylvania, was attending Friday's game against the Rockies with his family. Although he said he is not a Marlins fan in particular, Reinhard is a big baseball fan and thinks the sale will bring something positive to the team.\n\n\"[Jeter] has the experience of being with a winning organization and a winning club,\" Reinhard said. \"You would think he recognizes talent. He's been involved with it with the Yankees. They've built up a farm system as well. He's seen all aspects of a team from top to bottom. So I think it can only help.\"\n\nCarolyn Soucy, a representative of the Fisher House Foundation, which provides housing for military families, threw one the ceremonial first pitches before Friday's game.\n\nWearing her custom-made Marlins' jersey, Soucy said she is looking forward to seeing what Jeter can do for the franchise.\n\n\"It has to be a positive,\" Soucy said. \"We only can go up and do better.\n\n\"He was a great player and you can't ask for anything better than that. I just hope he can drive us the way he did his team as a player and one day take us to a World Series.\"\n\nAlex Cepero, a Cuban resident of Miami that has been a Marlins fan since 2009, said he was glad to see Loria sell the team because \"he is tired of seeing key players come and go on the Marlins roster for years.\"\n\n\"Whenever we finally put together a team with players of high caliber, we give them away,\" Cepero said. \"It's important that we have a new owner, but not just anyone. But with someone like Derek Jeter, I think winning is in his blood. I think he's going to put his heart into this team to make sure it reaches a high level.\"\n\nCepero said he is aware that even with a new owner the Marlins will likely need to make moves to bolster their roster and farm system that will take some time.\n\n\"I'm aware making this team better won't happen overnight,\" Cepero said. \"They have to work on improving this team's pitching staff overall. Jose Fernandez's death, it left a big hole in Miami. Bush"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_W._Bush", "score": 4, "id": "305921", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeb Bush"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeb_Bush", "score": 3, "id": "307464", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Derek Jeter"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derek_Jeter", "score": 2, "id": "310097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "First baseman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_baseman", "score": 2, "id": "310511", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Miami Marlins"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Marlins", "score": 4, "id": "310673", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Major League Baseball All-Star Game"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_All-Star_Game", "score": 3, "id": "312236", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jon Heyman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Heyman", "score": 2, "id": "334452", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jeffrey Loria"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Loria", "score": 3, "id": "548097", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tagg Romney"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tagg_Romney", "score": 3, "id": "822368", "type": "person"}], "body": "The Marlins sale process has quieted considerably since it became apparent that a deal wouldn't be wrapped up before the All-Star Game, as once had been hoped. To this point, three primary bidding groups were said to be vying to purchase the club from Jeffrey Loria.\n\nWhile there's still no evident movement toward resolution, that same inaction may have contributed to the loss of one possible buyer. It now seems the Fish are down to two prospective new ownership groups. Per Barry Jackson of the Miami Herald, the group that had included Wayne Rothbaum, Jeb Bush, and a host of former players is now out of the hunt. (Previously, that group had lost Tagg Romney but picked up Bush in the ever-changing bidding landscape.)\n\nRothbaum was the chief investor of that party, and reportedly was willing to lead the charge at a valuation of $1.17B. With that offer apparently waving in the wind, and with no resolution in sight, Rothbaum evidently determined it was no longer worth pursuing the club.\n\nThat said, it's also possible that the Rothbaum group's bid was never going to be quite to the Marlins' expectations. Jon Heyman of Fan Rag suggests that the aggregation of would-be owners may have been sitting in a lower range -- $1B to $1.1B.\n\nWhatever the case, the chase for the Marlins now seems to be down to two possible bidding groups. One, guided by Miami businessman Jorge Mas, seems to be a fairly straightforward outfit led by one primary investor who'd also be the control person. Per Heyman, Mas remains the \"best-financed\" pursuer. But there's still a possibility that MLB legend Derek Jeter could make a deal happen; while it's somewhat odd that he'd represent the control person, given that he would not be investing a significant portion of any sale price, Jeter (like Mas) is said by Jackson to have \"made progress in assembling the financing needed.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T13:13:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"uri": "mlbtraderumors.com", "title": "MLB Trade Rumors", "id": "2047"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:13:00", "url": "https://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2017/08/latest-on-bidding-for-marlins.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8621279", "image": "https://cdn.mlbtraderumors.com/files/2017/07/Marlins-Park-2-770x1024.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "13:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"658626", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Will Sherman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Will_Sherman", "score": 2, "id": "759225", "type": "person"}], "body": "Time for that parade, Miami. Where the ticker-tape at? Is it me, or do I already hear the distant, joyous cacophony of pots and pans being banged with wooden spoons? Along with the rising chant of a multitude singing, \"Ding dong, the witch is dead!\"\n\nLet us mark Aug. 11, 2017, as Independence for Marlins baseball fans -- the day despised, longtime franchise owner Jeffrey Loria reached an agreement to sell the club and ballpark, for $1.2 billion, to the consortium led by New York venture capitalist Bruce Sherman and fronted by former Yankees icon Derek Jeter, \"The Captain.\"\n\nThe deal must wend its way through the usual vetting and red tape, and the closing might not come until October. But that's OK. Parades take time to organize, right? The 16 investors in the winning group reportedly includes Michael Jordan, one of Jeter's good superstar buds. So M.J. can bring the victory cigars.\n\nThis is what most every Marlins fan has dreamed of, including the many who pledged to never support the club as long as Loria owned it but flock back into the fold the moment he sold.\n\nThe new owners will sweep in heroically on metaphorical white steeds by virtue of not being Jeffrey Loria. Any buying group would have enjoyed that honeymoon and bounce, but especially this one. Sherman is a philanthropist and Marlins fan. Jeter is Jeter, impeccable of reputation, imprimatur of success, and a magnet, surely, to the mass of transplanted New Yorkers and Yankees fans in South Florida.\n\n\"I can always talk about Derek, a kid I've known since his first step in major-league spring training,\" Marlins manager Don Mattingly said Friday as the news of the sale-agreement broke like party pinatas across South Florida. \"Derek has been successful in everything he's tried to do. There's nothing that leads you to believe he won't be successful [as an owner].\"\n\nSherman will be the money man with ultimate say, akin to what Stephen Ross is with the Dolphins or Micky Arison with the Heat. But Jeter, a relatively minor investor of $25 million of his own money -- and wouldn't we all love to be so rich that $25M was seen as a minor investment! -- supposedly will be the baseball man in charge of the on-field product. He'll be the Pat Riley.\n\nTogether money-man Sherman and baseball-guy Jeter will decide what to spend on who and how to end a 14-season playoff drought, fill Marlins Park and realize South Florida's full and untapped potential as a baseball market.\n\nOnce we're past the giddy euphoria of \"Loria's gone,\" what's next?\n\nWill Sherman spend more than Loria? Will Jeter direct that spending more wisely? Will the new owners pledge to keep cornerstone Giancarlo Stanton? Or will they jettison his escalating contract in a move that might be justified as financially prudent but would feel like a Loria-esque salary dump to fans? Oh, and will those disenfranchised fans who pledged to come back really do so?\n\nOne more: Does Derek Jeter's Hall of Fame career, business acumen and heft of reputation necessarily mean he knows how to run a baseball team?\n\nYes, that overarching question -- Now what? -- will loom ever larger as the sale becomes complete, power changes hands, Loria waves goodbye to the sound of one hand clapping, and Jeter is introduced as the new face of the franchise.\n\nBut that's for later.\n\nFor now, hear the sound of those windows banging open and feel the fresh air gusting in. See the tendrils of sunlight beaming through dissipating clouds.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 276, "textStart": 263}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355778", "details": {"liCnt": 27}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T22:04:00Z", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "source": {"uri": "miamiherald.com", "title": "Miami Herald", "id": "283"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:20:00", "url": "http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/greg-cote/article166819502.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355778", "id": "8742281", "image": "http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/greg-cote/2m9e0c/picture166819497/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/jeter", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "22:04:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"MIAMI (AP) - A person familiar with the negotiations says the Miami Marlins have told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter.\n\nJeter would a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman.\n\nThe person confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity Friday because the team had not commented publicly. The person said MLB has been told the sale price will be about $1.2 billion to the group, which includes more than 10 entities.\n\nSherman would be the controlling owner, the person said. Sherman has spent much of his financial career in New York and has also lived in Naples, Florida.\n\nThe person said Jeter will be in charge of baseball operations.\n\n___\n\nAP Baseball Writer Ronald Blum in New York contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nMore AP baseball: https://apnews.com/tag/MLBbaseball\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. droves to react to the news.\n\nFor some, Jeter's new role, which will reportedly encompass the business and baseball sides of the organization, marks a welcome departure for Loria, who has been referred to by some critics as the worst owner in sports, and who was voted in 2013 by a poll of ESPN readers as the most dishonest sports owner in the U.S.\n\nFor others, the easy comparison for Jeter is basketball legend Michael Jordan, who enjoyed a Hall of Fame career with the Chicago Bulls, then went on to buy the NBA's Charlotte Hornets.\n\nOthers simply noted how odd it would be to see Jeter, who spent his entire 20-season career with the Yankees, working for another team. "MIAMI (AP) -- A person familiar with the negotiations says the Miami Marlins have told Major League Baseball they intend to sign an agreement to sell the team to a group that includes former New York Yankees star Derek Jeter.\n\nJeter would a limited partner in the group led by venture capitalist Bruce Sherman.\n\nThe person confirmed the Marlins' plans to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity Friday because the team had not commented publicly. agreed to sell the franchise for $1.2 billion to the New York Yankees legend and his group led by New York businessman Bruce Sherman, a directly involved with the sale confirmed to USA TODAY.\n\nThe person spoke on condition of anonymity because the sale is not complete\n\nMLB: Can New York keep up with Boston?\n\nWeekend series: Three that impact the pennant race\n\nThe Miami Herald was the first to report the Sherman-Jeter group was in agreement with Loria.\n\nThe agreement is expected to be completed on Friday and submitted to Major League Baseball, which likely will not vote on the transaction at next week's owners' meetins in Chicago.\n\nJeter, who is expected to contribute about $25 million in the sale, is expected to run the Marlins' baseball operations department, according to the Herald, with Sherman serving as the club's \"control person\" regarding all matters relating to MLB and the central office.\n\nGALLERY: Derek Jeter: Yankees legendDerek Jeter through the years
